description:
So happy Jannah is in my neighborhood. As a Persian, I love middle eastern food, and this Iraqi restaurant does not disappoint. We were easily able to get a table for 4 at 6:30 on a Sunday, although the place filled up around 7-7:30.

I would recommend sharing some small plates and a main, as there are so many great items to choose from. 

Standouts from our visits include the mama ghanoush and the Kuzi. Both on the sweeter side. Also, thank you Jannah for bringing us so much bread- it's awesome. 

Prices are reasonable. Just a heads up that the menu prices for dinner have increased by $1.
author: Roya B.

description:
I've bene meaning to come here for years and my first experience with iraqi food was a good one! Also their portions are quite large and it's fairly easy to overorder fwiw. We got a three item mezze (hummus, baba ganoush, this pepper spread), this sort of lamb sausage pizza, a lamb shank in orka and tomato sauce, and their lamb dolma which is a lamb and rice mixture stuffed into a variety of vegetables (onion, chard, squash).

All were quite solid! The lamb shank was excellent and matched the sauce well. The various mezze all tasted kinda the same but in a good way. The pizza was interesting in that the dough kinda reminded me of cauliflower doughs that I've had. The dolma probably stole the show and I think we need to eat more mixtures of things stuffed into other things.
author: Misha T.

description:
This place is a treat for sure! 
The service was warm and Friendly and efficient!
I asked what to order and not only got the best recommendations  from the owner but also got a second affirmation from a customer! The juicy tender lamb shank dish and the yummy rice pudding was outstanding!! That alone was worth a repeat visit!
The baklava was I'm guessing , homemade and I haven't had any in years but do remember it not being as good as this was  an this was absolutely the bomb! 
I'm going back even if it is for the same dish and I usually try new things if I do a Yelpie repeat! 
I shall return and write more. It was reasonably priced as well!
author: Brian D.

description:
The place is awesome! Seriously one of those little San Francisco gems hiding under all of our noses, in plain sight where you least expect it.

I'm really excited to go back and try more, even though a lot of the dinner options are a little above my typical price range. One of the nice things about this place is that there actually are a surprisingly wide price range of items. For $10 you can get a pizza that will easily stuff one person, or you can go up in the $20s for items that are a little fancier.

I got 2x pizzas (one the falafel pizza, and the other the Urook pizza), and they were both spectacular. The Urook is a little more like traditional pizza with its sausage, onions, cheese, etc. but it is still clearly middle eastern in its flavors. Both are wonderful items unlike any typical pizza. This is one of my largest complaints with tikka masala pizza - in many places it's a lot like Italian/American pizza with just a slight difference. Here, there is no such confusion.

The servers are also extremely nice, and this place is clearly family owned and has been here a while. And they're FAST, so you can get an amazing meal on the go (especially if you use Allset like I did). I can't wait to go back!
author: Chris S.

description:
Five stars!! My fiancé is Middle Eastern with roots from Iraq/Dohuk. I came upon this place by chance on Yelp after looking up some food in the San Francisco area.

This place is a mom-and-pop business with excellent food! The Mezza, lamb fatoosh, lamb middle eastern salad, falafel pizza, Urook pizza, Kahi, and the kalecha were all on point!

For lots of Middle Eastern restaurants, starters typically comprise of pita bread and zaatar- an olive oil combination of finely-ground thyme and sesame seeds.

I have already gone here twice and the food is very consistent in quality. The lamb is absolutely grilled to perfection and tender, the falafel pizza a definite hitter with its unique combination of flavors, the Desserts with just the right amount of tang, sweetness, and a bit of savory flavor, these foods are reminiscent and representative of authentic Middle Eastern cuisine. 

Will definitely be a regular, even if my fiancé and I have to drive all the way to San Francisco from San Jose!
author: Sheena T.

description:
Stopped by here for lunch. 

Baba ganoush 5/5
Creamy, full of flavor. Garlicky. Slight bitter finish. 

Kenecha 4/5
Kinda funky taste due to cheese sprinkled on top. But when eaten as a whole, delicious! Nicely
 spiced, moderately sweet 

Kuzi 5/5
Nice crunch from the puff pastry. Tangy sweet. Well balanced flavors! Tender lamb inside 

Urook pizza 4/5
Crunchy chickpea crust. We asked for ours with lamb sausage and think it really benefited from the extra flavor! Overall delicious! 

Solid service 
Reasonable prices
Delicious food!?
Will be back!
author: J P.

description:
Iraqi-Californian food sitting right in the middle of SF? Take me there! The atmosphere is nice, the murals are calm and inviting, and the service was so friendly. I came for lunch right when they opened on a Sunday and enjoyed some selections off their smaller lunch menu. 

We started with the salmon kebab with fattoush salad, which was filled with delicious herbs, crunchy pita, lettuce, and spices. However, the portion was a little small and not particularly filling. We then had two of the phyllo dough entrees--the perdaplow was a dish of little dumplings filled with shredded chicken, rice, almonds, and golden raisins, surrounded by a sweet and tart apricot sauce with peas and chickpeas. The kuzi was a very similar dish, but with a filling of lamb instead. Both were fantastic, with bursts of flavor and crispy exteriors. 

Not feeling quite satisfied with just one salad, we then ordered an additional small plate salad--the Jannah salad, which consisted of cucumber, grilled eggplant, and grilled bell pepper. However, the salad was drenched in pomegranate molasses, which was unfortunately sickeningly sweet--it was hard to taste much else in the dish.

Overall, not a bad place for a casual lunch, though I think the overall experience would probably be better for dinner. Many of the dishes we tried weren't bad, but others could have been improved.
author: David K.

description:
My wife and I ate at Jannah last night, and it was absolutely phenomenal. The portions are huge, the pricing is fair, and, most importantly, the food is absolutely delicious.

We ordered a Mezza plate and really enjoyed the different ganoushes that it came with. There was easily enough food to be an excellent appetizer for 3 or 4 people, even though it was just the two of us. And they didn't skimp on the pita bread like other places often do.

We also got the falafel pizza, which was also excellent. It was easily large enough to be an entire meal, and the flavors were spot on. I can't wait to dig in to the left over piece for breakfast.

Finally, we also had one of the stuffed phylo dough dishes - the Kuzi. Holy cow this dish was good! The real star was the pomegranate-rosemary sauce. It was so sweet and tangy that I could imagine it as a dessert.

Also, we also had a glass of wine with dinner, and this place is incredibly generous with their pours.

The only downside to our evening at Jannah was that they were a little understaffed and we had to wait a bit for the server to come take our order and at the end of our meal to deliver our bill. But the food itself came out at a good pace and it did not feel like we were waiting forever for it to arrive.

I will summarize by saying that we will absolutely be back. This would be a great place to come with friends to share a meal family-style, and I highly recommend it.
author: Andy W.

description:
A relatively small but interesting restaurant serving Middle Eastern (Iraqi) food.  The menu is brief, often a sign that the food will be good!  And it was!
For starter, the Urook was a pizza like round base made with cooked cracked wheat with Pizza toppings.  Very tasty.

The main course was Kuzi, several golf ball-size dumplings assembled in a pyramid.  The dumplings are made of fillo pastry stuffed with flavorful shredded lamb and spiced rice.  The whole ensemble was on a bed of chick peas and pomegranate beads and a thick tangy pomegranate based reduction. Very tasty!

Kunafa was for desert, well made (oven baked melted white cheese, Mozzarella-like enshrouded with vermicelli, sprinkled with roughly ground pistachios and dripped with dates juice!  Needless to say the plate was spotless 5 minutes later!

Overall the service is very good, the old lady is a little sharp in her approach but get the job done!
author: Majeed F.

description:
Solid middle eastern food. I went here on a date, and we shared a humus plate, pita, tabouleh salad and a keba place.

It wasn't that busy, and service was excellent. The waiter was formal, polite, attentive and unobtrusive. The chicken part of the kebab unfortunately was tough, but the beef was excellent. I'd say this is more of a 3.5 star place but I wasn't blown away by anything and couldn't think of a reason I'd go out of the way to go back.
author: Jordan C.

description:
Love it when I discover amazing fusion gems in the city! This place fuses together the best of middle Eastern and California cuisine using brilliant culinary creativity. I tried the falafel pizza, yogurt sweet ravioli, dolmas, and hummus. They were all delicious and flavorful. The falafel pizza was really fun to eat and I love the crispy falafel flavor. The dolmas were incredibly delicious, filling, and fun to eat. The flavors of the yogurt ravioli were intense yet smoothed over by the yogurt flavor.

The ambiance is intimate and romantic. Service was great and the atmosphere is welcoming. Will definitely be coming back here!
author: Jacqui C.

description:
Jannah is a very cozy and unique hideaway, which is a rare find in this city.  I ordered the variety of pickles to start, Biriani stuffed phyllo dough, and Kelecha Ravioli for dessert, and enjoyed all under the clear blue sky that envelopes you in the interior.  
I've been thinking of this place ever since and am eager to expand my exposure to their menu.  Next up, the Sombosak stuffed phyllo dough and grape leaves.
author: Corrie W.

description:
(elsewhere) long line + long cook time = inhale my pre-dinner meal, box the rest, gtfo to be on time for irl frendos here. bc i'm always on time for food. :p suckas.

me: ::walks in w small food box::

frendo: "did you already eat dinner before coming?"

me: "lil food errand i had to go do."

frendo: "r u going to be ok to eat?"

me: "pshh." ::feels under the bench:: "any plugs? my phone's at 1%."

frendo: "u can borrow mine. i know it's upsetting if you can't take photos."

lol friends are the ones who know you best.

very SPACIOUS resto. cultural decor yet COMFORTABLE for families / all ages. friendly service. AROMATIC nuanced dishes set this place apart.

(^_^) Lamb Dolmas $18 (http://bit.ly/2xe989b)
fragrances happen at the back of your mouth #twss

(^_^) Perdaplow $18 (http://bit.ly/2wrBIXt)
aka chicken bog* fritters
*look that up

(-_^) Hummus Bi Tahini $5 (http://bit.ly/2wjSJnh)
it's hummus can't really f up hummus

(-_^) Beef Tikka w Rice $18 (http://bit.ly/2x0GJEx)
beef tenderish. ok but less wow than aromatic dishes

(-_^) Sun Dried Lime Juice $4
sourish not sweet. an acquired taste i'm sure

would i try to impress a DATE here? nah.
would i chillax & catch up w FRIENDS N FAM here? this.
author: Dan B.

description:
Jannah is a neighborhood gem. 
Really great Middle Eastern restaurant (Iraqi to be more specific). The Safeehat Falafel is a healthy upgrade of the pizza - falafel crust with plenty of grilled vegetables on top. The wraps are delicious and come with free lentil soup. The phyllo dishes are savory and light as well, especially the Sambosak. I'm looking forward to going back there and trying the dips.
author: Veronica L.

description:
Jannah serves amazing Middle Eastern food in the middle of NoPa, San Francisco.  It's the perfect restaurant to highlight San Francisco's diverse culinary culture and it's abundant choices of Michelin starred restaurants.  The ingredients are fresh and the courses are made with devotion to their cultural background.  

Jannah was recommended by my Iraqi buddy who I like to call Iranian to get him fired up.  

His usually response, "Dude there's a difference.  It's two completely different countries."  
Me, "Were they not both apart of the Persian empire at one time?" 
Him, "Yes, but it's different now."  
Me, "Tomato.  Toe-mato.  Same sh*t."  

I wouldn't say it's ideal to make an ignorant joke to San Franciscans.  They're a little sensitive even though the city is filled with tech-bros.  Now, I'm not a racist, but I'm more of a troll who likes to push buttons.  Anyway, my buddy doesn't eat pork cause he's Muslim.  I always try to sneak in bits of pork into his food, but he somehow figures it out.  I believe in equality, so I do it to my Jewish friends too.  

I was hesitate on going to Jannah because there is no pork on the menu.  I'm part Vietnamese and all we eat is pork.  I find it creepy when people don't eat pork.  Maybe the Jews and Muslims should start eating pork.  It'll probably bring peace in the Middle East.  Bacon saves lives.  

Jannah's service was fantastic.  It was true Middle Eastern service where they go the extra mile to accommodate your request and make you feel at ease.  It reminded me of the quality service I received when I visited the UAE, Egypt, Jordan, and Turkey.  I would say Middle Eastern service is only best by Japanese service.  Solid hospitality at Jannah.

Now, the food.  I went with the Tikka Kebabs with Hummus.  The chicken was definitely tasty and it was cooked perfectly to keep its moisture.  The sear marks with the tarragon marinate brought me back to the Middle East.  The beef kebabs came with the same sear marks, but it had a thyme marinate.  The thyme marinate gave the beef a barely noticeable mint flavor.  

The hummus was fantastic.  It was fresh and creamy; it wasn't bland or uninspiring.  It was the perfect dipping sauce for the kebab.  I asked my "Iranian" buddy who came up with hummus.  The Jews or the Muslims?  He had no idea.  I asked the same question in the Middle East. The Jews said they did. Muslims said it was them.  

Now, I know the real reason Jews and Muslims don't get along. They both laid claim to hummus like Jerusalem. Forget searching for the fountain of youth.  Go find out who came up with hummus.

Lastly, Jannah is a great restaurant for some quality Iraqi food.  The service is superb; it's only best by the fresh ingredients in its dishes.  The brightly lit restaurant keeps the atmosphere upbeat.  I would definitely recommend Jannah to anyone looking for a comfortable dining experience.
author: Steve N.

description: Great food. Will be coming back again soon. Only dropping stars because they had no draft beer at all since they forgot to refill their taps. I was really looking forward to it, but tried one of their Lebanese wines and it was delicious
author: Eduardo S.

description: Awesome place and super sweet and attentive service! Salmon kabab was cooked perfectly, falafel pizza was amazing. Also great wine
author: Shannon M.

description: Great family run restaurant with a cozy and welcoming feel and fantastic middle eastern food.  My go to is usually the falafel pizza, eggplant, jannah salad and lentil soup for a quick meal for 2 to go that won't break the bank.  Or if I'm in the mood to stay for a nice sit down dinner I'll get some hummus and the dolmas dish and finish it off with the excellent baklava .  Everything I've had so far is excellent!
author: Stevan D.

description:
Lovely, knowledgeable staff and great food. My friend's been raving about this place so I tried it.
We shared the mezzo platter- baba ganoush, carrot hummus and (regular) hummus which came with pickled veg and warm pita. It was amazing. I loved the smokey eggplant. Four people shared three courses and there was still leftovers. We ate family style although the main courses are meant for one person. The lamb stuffed in grape leaves, zucchini and onion were everyone's favorite. It came in a green sauce-yum. We also had a shrimp and scallop dish and chose a the chicken with pomegranate in filo dough. The portions are large. We agreed that two mains would have been right. 
We wrapped up our meals with an amazing cheese sweetened with filo and honey. I never had anything like it before and I really loved it. I highly recommend this place!
author: Susan B.

description:
I live two blocks away but, unfortunately, it took me six years to notice the restaurant.  That was my loss.  When my partner and I finally went in, we found ourselves inundated with spectacularly prepared, delicious and interesting food-- lots of it.  Wafa, the lady who owns and runs the restaurant with her husband, engaged us in a friendly conversation and proudly told us about her menu-- and she deserves to be very proud of her food.

That was two years ago and we have been back at least ten times-- just ourselves, with visiting friends and with large groups-- especially after the Fall 2017 fires up north, when we had lots of refugees staying with us due to eh hotels all being full.  When Wafa realized that most at our table were from the fire zone-- many not knowing if their homes were still standing-- she brought over dessert after dessert, all free, to cheer everyone up a bit.  On our trips there afterward, she made a point of asking us if all were OK and had a home to return to, (they did.)

Last week, we took two local foodies there who have eaten their way around the world and had not known of Janna.  They were totally blown away by their meals and declared it their new favorite restaurant. 

On top of all of this, Janna's prices are reasonable, if not downright cheap, for the quality of the food they serve on a daily basis.  GO!  NOW!
author: Steve G.

description:
We went here for dinner after seeing it on KQED. Ambiance is good but too bright. They could lower the lights a bit. 
We started with Baba Gonush and Grape leaves. BG was good but really small portion. Looks big but they spread it thin. Grape leaves filling was great. A bit tangy for my taste. But overall great start. 
I can't vouch for the non veg dishes. From the look of my kids plates, it must have been good as they finished their plates. My vegetarian dish was a 7/10. The spinach sauce was amazing. The rice soaked in it was great too. The eggplant and veggies lacked flavor. 
For dessert we got Baklava and Kahi. Baklava was good served in a cream yogurt sauce. Baklava could use some more honey. Kahi I've never had before. I would pass next time. The Rasberry base served was a good touch. 
Our Korean waiter was amazing. He was pleasant polite and very courteous. The lady (I think then owners wife) needs to stay in the back or take some pleasantry classes. No smile with a rude tone.
author: Soham P.

description: 5 stars for the ambience food and friendly service. We saw them on Check please and decided to go. We made the right decision. They have a beautiful old fashioned elegant space with large windows and a sky painted ceiling. We ordered the falafel pizza which was unique and absolutely delicious with a side of Japanese grilled eggplant. My daughter ordered the lamb shank. It was perfect the portions are large and any dish can be shared between 2. I plan on coming back again soon
author: Ashish G.

description:
Delicious and incredible service!! I really appreciated how the waiter was so attentive and made sure we were happy with our plates. Great food -- I'd strongly recommend the baba ganoush -- and great atmosphere. Jannah is cozy and comfortable but also has tables for large parties. I also appreciated how big the portions were!!

Overall I'd strongly recommend!
author: Lee C.

description: After walking by this place for years and always feeling curious, I can't believe it took me so long to try it! Everything we had was delicious. The kuzi and vegetarian dolmas were my favorite dishes, and my partner loved the mezza with an assortment of pickled vegetables. We had the kanafa for dessert, which I also highly recommend. The service was incredible--staff were kind, friendly, and attentive. I'll be back! Immediately one of my favorite restaurants.
author: M. A.

description:
We learned about this restaurant from watching KQED's Check Please! and based many of our food choices from recommendations from the show. We were not disappointed!

We ordered the falafel pizza and the grilled Japanese eggplant for our appetizers. Definitely my favorite falafel ever! So flavorful and not too heavy or greasy the way some fried falafels can be. The pomegranate sauce for the eggplant was heavenly. Even after all the eggplant was eaten, we kept dipping pita bread and our forks into the sauce. So good!

For entrees we ordered the lamb shank (option 3), the phyllo stuffed with chicken, and the vegetable dolma. All three were so delicious! The flavors were interesting and full, but nothing was too salty or heavy. The lamb shank was super tender and falling off the bone. The phyllo was crunchy with a sweet sauce that complemented the chicken stuffing. And the phyllo was not super greasy! The vegetable dolma was accompanied by a tasty yogurt sauce and the stuffed tomato in the middle really completed the dish.

For dessert we ordered the phyllo stuffed with cream accompanied by a raspberry purée and the semolina with milk and rose water, drizzled with chocolate and chopped pistachios. I really loved the phyllo. It was crunchy on the outside and creamy on the inside. And the raspberry purée was plenty sweet to accompany the unsweetened phyllo and cream. Together they were just sweet enough without being overly so. Personally I did not love the semolina (I just thought it was okay), but my dad loved it. I will say that the amount of rose water was just perfect. Enough that it really stood out, but not enough that it came across as ridiculously perfumes.

Tl;dr: Highly recommend this restaurant! The food is super tasty without being overly salty or heavy.
author: Hsin May T.

description: I'm an extremely picky eater. Not much of a meat eater. My friends loved the lam shank dishes! Large portions. My favorite was the tabouli and falafel pizza. Be sure to save room for dessert and Arabic coffee!!!
author: Halla T.

description:
Watched it on Check Please! 
Trekked over from Oakland to check it out and it was totally worth it. As a vegetarian I give it a solid B for offering many veggie options including the falafel "pizza"

Looking forward to returning =)
author: Lissy R.

description:
I've been going to Jannah for at least 4 years now and brought family and friends here too. Everyone loves it! The food is delicious, amazing service and the owners are delightful. 

If you haven't been there yet...it's a MUST!!!
author: Martin F.

description: I can't understand those that talked of small portions. We ordered far too much food and were stuffed. It was all good, and interesting. We've tasted various cuisines from the Middle East, and this added some interesting additions to the many dishes we've tried. Some of the food was old standby's like Lentil Soup, which was quite good. Service was quite good, we we're lovingly taken care of, with our only regret being one dessert being out that night. Highly recommend.
author: David H.

description: Food and service was excellent!  Love the chicken kabobs. The meat was amazingly juicy and full of flavor!  Good size portion! We will be back!
author: Daniel A.

description: Excellent Mezze - the baba ganoush was out of this world as were the pickled vegetables. Generous servings. Chicken kebab and beef kebab were great served with an amazing salad. The baklava was served on a safran rice sauce and left us wanting more. Delightful waitress (think she might have been the owner). We would love to come back for more.
author: Martin N.

description:
Jannah is a great, little neighborhood gem!! It's a solid spot for lunch and the food is very good & affordable. I recently ordered catering from Jannah and had an excellent experience. Wasa is so pleasant and helped me order the right amount of everything for my group size. We discussed my budget and she was very accommodating & did not try to uptick me on the menu. I set the budget and the head count, and we made it work in a great way.  

On the menu, I absolutely love their baba ganoush. It's a little bit smoky. The zuza ganoush in incredible!! It almost tastes like dessert (kind of like a carrot hummus). The grape leaves are also a favorite of mine. I have not tasted it, but the falafel pizza was a huge hit with my guests. 

If you have dietary restrictions, they are very gluten-free friendly and have plenty of vegetarian options.
author: Kandace K.

description: Delicious authentic Middle Eastern food and service. The Mezza was very flavorful. I loved the Fatoosh salad. The Lebanese wines were a great accompaniment. Then the dolma was just amazing.
author: Tina D.

description: Excellent food. Great service. Lots of space making it good for groups. Also, the food is very shareable. The dips and filo dough based entres are delicious. I look forward to visiting this place again when I am back in SF.
author: Mo A.

description: My friend from out of town wanted to test me to dinner. We decided on Jannah. We had a delicious meal, followed by desserts. The plating was art!  The food was scrumptious!
author: Janet W.

description:
Food wise, a solid 3 star, no highs or lows but the reason why I am giving it 4 star is because of the lady who works there

We had a large party, roughly 20 people or so, and was allowed to order separate checks + no gratuity included. She went through a lot of trouble to get it done when she honestly didn't have to so for that I was grateful. I honestly would have loved to have the pre fixe group menu but sadly not everyone at the table wanted it

Overall Thoughts

I'll have to come back again to give the food another chance to see if my mind will change
author: Eddie W.

description:
I've been here twice and don't see a reason to go back a third time. The menu looks interesting, but the food is fairly bland. Tried 5 different dishes and they were all slightly disappointing. 

Go elsewhere. There are better, similar options.
author: Brett J.

description:
Always delicious and reasonably priced. The food portions and very good and there is usually space for a small group. We have tried a number of dishes and literally all of it has been good. 

It's also a little nicer and easier to have a conversation there.
author: John-Mark I.

description:
I was excited to try this Iraqi/Middle Eastern restaurant. The first menu item that caught my eye was the falafel pizza. This is a fun appetizer -- crispy falafel crust topped with pesto, eggplant, tomatoes and feta. 

The perdaplow was outstanding -- little crisp pockets of phyllo dough filled with shredded chicken, spices, almonds and currants. The lamb shank was a little under seasoned but it's a very substantial dish and I took home nearly half as leftovers. Overall the portion sizes are generous and they have $5 wines by the glass!

It's definitely a neighborhood spot off the beaten path. We went with a group of friends and it's a great place to catch up. Even on a Friday night, it wasn't too crowded and service was attentive.
author: Jenny N.

description: We had a lovely and satisfying meal here on a recent Friday night. The dolma appetizers were tasty. It was the first time I had them with tomatoes sauce. We loved the Kuzah and the rice and veggies along with the salmon kebab. the pomegranate juice was way too sweet for my husband, but I enjoyed my red wine from Lebanon. The place felt very authentic. We'll be back.
author: Mira S.

description: Great affordable food. Perfect for takeout. The Falafel Pizza is amazing and this is the only place I know of that has it. My roommates and I get takeout here all the time and they never disappoint.
author: Greg M.

description:
This place is amazing! My wife and I were blown away by the uniqueness and authentic-ness of the cuisine. And on top of that, everything tasted great. Our favorite dishes were the Kelecha and the Safeehat Falafel Pizza.

We had a lot of good meals during our weeklong trip between San Francisco and Los Angeles, but this was by far our favorite. Plan on your next meal out at this restaurant - you will not be disappointed!!
author: Rick C.

description: Really tasty spices and good quality ingredients. I also enjoyed the atmosphere. Even our picky kids enjoyed most of the food. We'll definitely be back.
author: Seth C.

description:
Creamy homemade hummus, pickled veggies, tabouleh, salad, grilled chicken and salmon kebabs with a basket of fresh pita bread...All for $11!!?? Yes!

This has got to be one of the best lunch deals in town! Lamb and beef kebabs are also options for the lunch special and you can choose from a few other sides instead of the hummus.

Just for fun, we shared some chicken barley soup. It was rich and hearty - the kind of meal I imagine a middle eastern shepherd enjoying pre-dawn before a day of wandering rugged hills with his flock.

I tried the salted lime juice - boy, was it strong and bitter. I recommend mellowing it out with a generous infusion of ice water.

Service was good and we practically had the whole place to ourselves. It's a great little spot for a healthy, delicious mid-week, mid-town lunch.
author: Carole B.

description:
Came here for dinner last night as it was recommended by a friend. I was surprised at how quiet it was as the food was great. 

We had the starter plate with hummus and pita - so good! I then had the chicken tikka with rice which was also good but I loved the dip plate more. Wine was $5 a glass and the service was great. It's a family run restaurant and you can feel the love they have put into the restaurant. I'll be going back to try the falafel.
author: Mira B.

description:
The food is excellent. It's Californified Iraqi. Very nicely done. Every dish we ordered was skilfully executed. My faves were the Urook, the falafel pizza (the crust is falafel!) and the perdaplow.
One star off for not getting the tea right. The "Arabic" tea is a regular black tea. The mint tea has no tea, just a mint tisane.
author: C J.

description: Chose this place while in the area for lunch. While the food was mediocre the service was horrible. A female waitress during lunch hours was just not customer friendly or maybe to us. She forgot to provide a plastic bag for our take home food but  frankly seemed like she couldn't be bothered. One and done for me......a lot better places then this joint
author: N And N K.

description:
Plates loom good but doesn't taste good
It is probably on the healthy side with no salt or oil
author: Mohammad S.

description: I loved this food when they were Yaya Restaurant and I still love it. Outstanding and delicious food and warm, friendly service. Can't wait to return.
author: Esther L.

description:
Quiet, spacious restaurant in the Haight area serving Iraqi and other Mediterranean cuisine.


---- ENTREES ----

Chicken Kebabs: 4.5 stars
Juicy and well-seasoned.  Excellent kebabs.

Perdaplow:  5 stars
I've never had anything like this before, and it blew me away.  Phyllo pastry pie filled with shredded chicken and almonds, served with apricot / peach chutney with raisins.

Lamb Shank with potato and garbanzo beans: 4 stars

Kuzi: 4 stars

Mazkoof: 4 stars
Smashed trout 

Hummus: 3 stars
Better than Tribe and Sabra packaged hummuses, but slightly on the clumpy and watery side of the fresh hummuses I've had, especially in this city.

Tabouleh: 4 stars
Standard fresh tabouleh, the citrus is balanced, nothing objectionable about it.

---- DESSERT ----

Kahi: 4 stars
I love hot desserts. Phyllo pastry stuffed with a cheesy custard filling almost savoury, in a pool of rose or raspberry (?) sauce.

Knafa: 4 stars
Looks legit, prettiest knafeh in SF, oozy cheese, but flavour was just okay. Not sweet enough unfortunately.

I'd definitely like to come back here to verify the quality of more dishes, but for one meal alone (and takeout, too!) this restaurant has earned itself 4.5 stars for quality.
author: Letitia L.

description:
Lamb shank with okra was under seasoned. Falafel pizza was good. Grilled eggplant was good but sauce was too sugary - like sweet n sour chinese sauce. Babaganoush was nice. 

Very disappointed with lamb shank. The best lamb shank is made by Third Eye but it's a bit of a drive
author: Yash R.

description: Just got take out. Wonderful flavors! A lot for your buck. Friendly place. Fun to see folks sitting around and relaxing over a good meal in traditional garb next to others dressed like me. Not the most exciting neighborhood, so I'd go just for the restaurant. I'm glad it's nearby. Nice place. Amazing flavors. I'll definitely be going back! Street parking wasn't difficult.
author: Yvonne R.

description: The food is great. We went there after a super long day and the place definitely didn't disappoint us. I ordered a perdaplow, which has cardamom flavored chicken koftas cooked in apricot sauce with dry fruits. It was delicious and the chicken with cardamom was simply mouthwatering. The mezze platter was equally good. Their baba ganoush is a must-try. Cannot miss this place if you're around Fulton!
author: Kavya J.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Saturday night, no wait. Service was top notch. A bit classy, but can be casual if you want it to be.

We were not too hungry and just ordered the jannah salad and falafel pizza, which were both very good. They give you some pita with oil. Portions were good.  

 I'd like to come back and try the lamb entrees.
author: Juliana P.

description:
I have been meaning to come here for the past 5 years, and I'm embarrassed that it took so long given how great it was.  This is a rarity of a family run restaurant in San Francisco - it's authentic and terrific.  The food is excellent, service is warm, portions are extremely generous and the price points are reasonable. 

My wife and I shared the falafel "pizza", an order of kebabs with rice (lamb/chicken mix) and the Perdaplow (with chicken).  Almost everything on the menu sounded great, and it was hard to decide what to try.  Everything was well prepared, fresh, and tasted great.  

The food is Iraqui - similar enough to Persian, Turkish and other middle eastern food I have had.  The city has a dearth of good middle eastern place - I'm really glad to have discovered this place....better late than never.
author: Daniel W.

description: One of my favorite places in SF, which is saying something. The flavors here are so unique and beautiful. The mama ghanoush is a favorite- like baba, only with pomegranate molasses in place of tahini. It sounds odd, but it is so wonderful. I'd suggest starting by trying some of their dips, and then ordering out some kabobs or lamb shank if you're a carnivore. Great flavors, ample portions, good prices. I also like that it's a family restaurant, and that there are Middle Eastern families at tables, chatting in their native tongue. It's clearly a community establishment, and that makes me happy, too.
author: Tania L.

description:
For those of you who love (really love) the flavors of Middle Eastern food, Jannah Restaurant on 1775 Fulton Street, at Masonic will haunt your tastebuds demanding you return for more. Apparently once called Yaya, Jannah is a small, one chef owner  restaurant with a second chef who works there when the main man is not there. I love (really love) Middle Eastern Food and this restaurant is one of the most unique combinations of the flavors of the region in collaboration with hints of the Californian cuisine. Innovative, succulent, a little spice (maybe more if you ask ??), the menu is unique and not fussy.


I had a the lentil soup with sumac which was thick, satisfying, comfort food just like lentil soup should be. Then came the Safeehat Falafel which was like a Middle Eastern pizza. It was a perfect crust made of garbanzo beans covered with a thin wash of pesto, followed by eggplant, roasted bell peppers, onions, mushrooms, tomato and topped with feta (not super salty thankfully) and goat cheese. Vegetarian heaven. It's a generous dish and two people could easily make it a center of a meal, with one of their wonderful sounding salads, a dip, coffee, wine, desert...omg...I have to go back.

As I savored the Safeehat Falafel, I read the menu. Crazy, right? Incredibly delicious  sounding salads, really interesting dips and other main courses to try alone and with friends. 

Another plus: a nice selection of wines by the bottle and by the glass.


The prices are way reasonable and the food is outstanding. It looks like a very comfortable place to have a gathering of good friends and family for celebrations, or for no reason at all. 

This is a hidden gem and it's the real deal. 

I think i'm moving in.

url: http://www.yayacuisine.com/menu.htm
author: yelper y.

description: Fantastic service and food. I had the mama's dolma and it was the best middle eastern dish that I've had in the city and maybe the best dish period. My wife had the vegetable dolma and really enjoyed it. We also had the falafel pizza for an appetizer and it was outstanding. I definitely recommend this place for anyone who's looking for a great bit to eat at an extraordinary value.
author: Kristopher U.

description: Very normal restaurant barely meets expectations..  even the taste is not super delicious as I heard .. the old lady waitress was a bit tough.. I don't recommend it and will not go back
author: Noor H.

description: Great food, great service, great ambience. A bit out of the way at Fulton and Masonic but well worth it.
author: Paul N.

description: Coming from NYC with a mindset of  having the most exquisite restaurants. Oh boy did Jannah surprise me or what. It was a beautiful 1st dining experience in San Fran! They've actually set the bar high for the rest of the trip. The service was excellent, their menu and dishes are unlike the other boring Middle Eastern places.  Jannah is a unique Iraqi / Middle Eastern gem with a little Western twist.  I will definitely pay them a visit whenever I am in the area.  This is a must of you are exploring authentic food.
author: Sunshine A.

description: I loved my falafel pizza, but my friends were disappointed with their dishes (overdone lamb, underwhelming masgouf). Very friendly and accommodating staff and pleasant atmosphere.
author: Claire B.

description: The food is amazing, the ambiance is great, the service is fantastic and all around great.  I really recommend it and would expect that it will continue to be a top notch restaurant.
author: Jay W.

description: Excellent Iraqi and Middle Eastern with a twist! Will be dining here every time while in San Francisco
author: Ghada S.

description:
This place is so amazingly good. The owners are wonderful people, the food is always excellent, and it's never too loud. 

Highlights include the mugdara salad, the dolmas, the Safehat falafel and the zuzu ganoush
author: Ninna G.

description:
Went with friends tonight for the first time. Very impressed. Nice decor and large cloth napkins!
Food was so good. Had the lamp!!!  fall of the bone soft!!! we started with Baba Ghanooge. So good! My friend had a chicken and meat  kabob. Like the fact they take it off the skewer and plate it.The crispy salad that goes with it is excellent.  The amount of food they give you is on the large size. Service is point on!!! EXCELLENT. Large restaurant and tables are not stacked
on top of each other. Parking at Lucky's is ok. Will be back. oh, NOT overly salted or over spiced!!
author: Peter F.

description: Food is delicious. It's not a "fancy" restaurant ambience wise etc, but very reasonable priced (under $20 entrée and $5-8 apps) and food was tasty! The alcohol menu is very standard as well, no cocktails etc and wines brands won't impress you - but the corkage fee is reasonable, so bring your own. I had the eggplant (babaga-something) dip, Hummus, and the filo stuffed meat and rice thing, all very yums.
author: Phantom Of Yel P.

description: It's been awhile since I ate here the last. The dinner was so delicious! I love their eggplant dish, salmon and chicken perdaplow. We'll go back there again next week. The waiter is super nice. I love the quiet space to have a conversation over wine. The price is a bit high as a regular dinner but it's so worth it!
author: Erena S.

description: Place is a cosy family owned restaurant, serving Iraqi cuisine with a twist. We ordered the Lamb shank , quzi, aubergine salad and kunafa .it was a pleasant experience overall. Nice main course dishes and appetizers. Dolmas were great.
author: Mary P.

description: Excellent restaurant. The falafel pizza is stellar and the cardamom infused baklava is to die for!
author: Chirag C.

description: This is a great neighborhood spot. Owners are wonderful and accommodating. Tell them what you want and it will happen. They are from Iraq and they aim to please for American taste!
author: Michael B.

description:
Love this place. It's not too crowded, but it should be, because all of their food is delicious. I come here with my boyfriend, and we over-order from every section on the menu and stuff our faces until we can barely move. Then we walk around the surrounding neighborhood, which is lovely, to digest. 
The food is great, and the prices are great. Love that Jannah is close by.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I discovered Jannah about a month ago and have been back with different friends three times. The food is excellent. Their menu offers so many choices and the portions are very generous. 
This Middle Easter Iraqi food is made by an amazing chef. The ambiance is lovely and the service is great. There are choices for those who are vegan, vegetarians, as well as meat and fish eaters. Oh, their desserts are special and scrumptious. Even though I am not a wine drinker, I notice they have an interesting wine list. I can guarantee once you experience Jannah's food, you will also want to keep returning as I have, to try new dishes and to continue this gastronomic paradise. Ilana
author: Ilana G.

description: Fantastic food, lovely music, very sweet service and relaxing atmosphere. Really loved the food! Please, check it out. I promise you it's very authentic, like homemade but classy!
author: Ziad A.

description: lovely and good food , Felafel and  Kuzi are the best
author: Ahmad Y.

description:
Staff extremely nice.  Food is very good healthy and tasty.  Went once last weekend and had to
Come back for take out the next week.  Glad it is just down the street.
author: B K.

description:
Delicious, and surprisingly uncrowded for a Wednesday night. 

We were 4 and shared everything:

Mezze - choice of 3 dips - all very tasty. 
"Pizza" - very interesting, falafel flattened and covered with topping. Yum! and Unique
Eggplant appetizer - sauce is very sweet - almost too sweet, but, great with the eggplant
"ravioli" - should be a dessert! But also very tasty. 
Grape leaves (app) - probably our favorite. Juicy and plump

Dolma main - large, enough for 2 people (we all shared it). Very different from the grape leaf appetizer, as our waiter told us. 

Overall - was quiet, great ambiance, very reasonable for how much food we got and how quickly. We'll be back!!
author: Mimosa A.

description: Amazing food, great ambience and courteous servers. Had the special of the day - scallops with eggplant and cauliflower. It was to die for.
author: Meg S.

description: Delicious unique Iraqi cuisine with dishes you might not find anywhere else, beautiful intimate decor and reasonable prices.
author: Arkady I.

description:
Being from Michigan, we know Arabic restaurant food. The Kuzi dish was excellent. The spices were perfect. 

The bamia (okra) with lamb shank was very good. 

The eggplant with Parmesan didn't belong on an Arabic menu. It tasted unusual but ok. 

Service friendly and ambience and presentation very well taken care of. I can see why the restaurant has been amply reviewed by media. 

Turkish coffee was well prepared. 

Don't stop by here without trying the kahi dessert.
author: S. R.

description:
After two delicious visits I am ready to award five stars.

Dishes sampled:
- chicken kabob
- salmon kabob
- Yaya grape leaves
- Sheakh Muhshee

All were very, very good and large portions. The salmon kabob is a must-try; I've never had salmon kabobs before and thought they would taste strange but was happily surprised. Eggplant and lamb dishes were also great. Family run restaurants with good service.
author: Jon B.

description:
Nice ambiance, and pretty yummy food. One vegan entrée, the okra. Good hommous. Nice artwork. House wine is a good deal.

Pricy for what it was, though. And vegan entrées cost the same as meat ones -- even though the ingredients are cheaper. Or did I eat the gold leaf without noticing?
author: Alec F.

description:
I've stop by with my family to have a family dinner. Services, menu explanation and vine suggestions were done done quickly and in very delicate way.

Portion size, taste and everything just exceeded my expectations.

Lamb, baklava and Turkish coffee are outstanding and better than in other places I've tried.
author: Mikhail B.

description: The salmon kabob is delicious. Served with humus. Very nice atmosphere as well. Authentic vibe. I will return to explore more of their menu and hope they dial-in the dishes to be more generally consistent.
author: Rylan C.

description: One of the best Arabic food spots I've had in the Bay Area. The food is authentic and are huge portions, at least in my opinion. Amazing pomegranate sauce that compliments some of the spiced entrees. I also found one of my favorite desserts knafeh!! Food does take some time to prepare so keep that in mind, if you go in starving order apps. But they owners are really kind and took care of us. We'll be back!
author: Marwa K.

description:
This seems like a great family-ran restaurant. We came here on a Friday and the place was completely empty. Not sure why because the food is great and the service friendly. Our waitress spent some time to explain Iraqi food to us, which was very nice of her.

We shared a bottle of wine, the combination appetizer plate, the lamb shank and a filo dough wrapped entree. 

The appetizer plate had hummus, baba ganoush and a red bell pepper spread. All tasted fresh and well made. I also love the bread that came with it.

The lamb shank was absolutely divine -- falling off the bone and had great flavor. The filo dough dish, I wasn't as fond of because the sauce was so overpoweringly sweet and sour, you can't really taste anything else. The portions were big, I think one appetizer and one entree would be enough for two people.
author: Alice W.

description: We had a really great experience at Jannah last night! Our waiter was so kind and accommodating. The food was delicious! Definitely recommend the kelecha and kuzi! Both have a delicious combination of spices. The ambiance was very authentic. Would definitely come back in the future!
author: Sarah P.

description: I love their falafel pizzas. They always taste freshly made which is good. But! This time I ordered the sambosek phyllo- and it must have been old or gone bad because I was sick in bed for 3 days with food poisoning, a fever, almost having to go to the hospital. I would not go back again.
author: Saskia S.

description:
Quiet, fancy, clean, great service, tasty....what else could you ask for.

I stopped in on a visit to the City, and found Jannah by accident (on Yelp), dropped by for dinner, was the only person in the pre-rush hour, got in and out quickly with a sampling of Kuzi and a desire to go back. 

The server was awesome, he knew the food, was personable, the place was spotless....and the price was very reasonable! I'm a long distance fan!
author: Brandon C.

description:
*a hidden gem for middle eastern food in the area*
[lamb!]
[hugeplatters]

This place is deceivingly impressive. I feel this place has reverse discrimination. People avoid it at first glance because it looks very nice inside. To my surprise I came here for lunch to find it's incredibly reasonably priced, the food is delicious and
plentiful, and the service accommodating and attentive. 

This is my go to spot after I get my haircut across the street and I'm excited to try the phyllo dough meals next time. Their lamb skewers have been cooked fantastically and all the sides are unique and flavorful. 

It's always been quiet when I've been there but this place deserves a crowd.
author: Kevin T.

description: Just finishing incredible lamb hind shank dinner here!! Wife had Kuzi, a phyllo dish full of an exotic flavors. Cinnamon, pomegranate , almonds, ginger  sauce bathed the phyllo, while the lamb melted in my mouth. It was covered w carmelized onion, roasted bell in pomegranate and yogurt sauce, We'll certainly return when we come back to SF.
author: Jack J.

description: The greatest restaurant ever!!! The flavors are really authentic and deep. The chief does his own recipes and the food is somthing that you will never taste elsewhere..
author: Shahad A.

description:
This place is so delicious; a true neighborhood gem! I'm always shocked that it's not packed. 
My favorite is the Mediterranean pizza!!! Seriously, you will not be disappointed.
author: Oona Q.

description:
I live a half block away. This restaurant serves really delicious Middle Eastern cuisine.  I am not an expert on the region's cuisine and its variances, but I eat a lot and I've eaten enough good Middle Eastern food to know that Jannah is putting out some great stuff and it is also a little different and creative.  I loved the dolmas entree (which has lamb in it) and the salmon kebabs were very good.  Same with the fatoosh and tabouleh.  And that za'atar in olive oil? Yum.  I can't wait to try some of the phyllo specialties. And all very affordable, all the way down to the $5 glass of wine with my dinner (it would be a serious omission if I did not mention that).

My picky 80-year-old foodie parents loved it also. I have no idea why this restaurant is not more crowded. Plus service is good and they are really nice.  Thanks Jannah!
author: CC L.

description:
The beer on tap was sort of bunk, but there was a time on this earth when there was no beer...I just thought I would mention it. Something new... Awesome. Every thing we ordered was tasty.  
We shared a few dishes, all were wonderful. 
Safeehat Falafel was great, totally different than anything I have ever had. 
the lentil soup was great. The hummas and  baba ghanooge were perfect.  
The service was good and the food came fairly fast. 
What's up with the decor....
author: Ben M.

description: The most delicious Middle Eastern food! I came here with my family and we definitely were not disappointed! The lamb tikka is mouthwatering. The sambosak is great especially if you're a vegetarian. The baklava and chai to top off the food was just right. The service was over the top. Very kind and attentive. I can't wait to come back!
author: Tarana C.

description: Awesome Iraqi food! Highly recommended! Our waitress was Iraqi, very nice women. It was three of us, ordered three meals to share, all very tasty!
author: Agnes K.

description: Great hummus, amazing salmon kebab, huge portions, great (reasonably priced) wine and impeccable service! The deco is also very inviting and makes you feel luxurious. So happy to discover my new favorite Mediterranean spot!
author: Marlène S.

description: Came in for an amazing lunch today!   Great flavor combinations in all dishes.  Highly recommend the grape leaves (like no other I have has before) and the falafel pizza.  Staff was friendly and helpful.  Enjoy!
author: Dana B.

description:
Service is friendly and the waiter is super cute.

Location: Kinda in the middle of nowhere and very foggy.

Ambiance: Restaurant is very spacious and formal. I don't quite get the concept. Will work better with mom and pop feeling I think.

Food: I ordered Kuzi, which was suggested by the waiter as the more exotic selection. I'm an adventurous eater, so of course I ordered it. Kuzi is a big round phyllo dough with rice + raisin + lamb + almond inside. The phyllo dough is crispy and nice but the sauce that it came with is way too tangy, but if I don't use the sauce, it'd be kinda flavorless.

I just pretend that the waiter selection was good, but it was actually kinda hard to eat :(
author: Novalina N.

description: Love this local spot for its reasonably priced, consistent and fresh med fare.  It's our go-to for their dips, dolmas, herby salads, falafel pizza, perdaplow (phyllo dough filled w chicken w a yummy sauce), and kelecha (almost desserty). The folks who work here are always very sweet, and I'm so glad they're in the neighborhood.  I can't imagine having anything but a good experience here...
author: Sophie D.

description: If you want a very unique experience in exotic well thought out and delicious Iraqi food, Jannah is your place. Chef Yahya Salih creates dishes that are inspired by his mother's cooking of food that is specific to the city of Mosul to the north of Baghdad and at the same time influenced by his many years of cooking California cuisine.  The restaurant itself is beautiful and has seating area in the back that consist of benches with throw rugs and pillows where you feel that you are in the Middle East. There is a full bar with a great selection of wines and beers. If you are tired of the old typical Middle Eastern food of falafel and gyros, you will for sure be taking a different journey into a side of Middle Eastern food that not too many restaurants dare to venture into. The Safeehat Falafel is unbelievable and all the dishes made with phyllo dough have that crispiness of the flaky phyllo which wraps the perfectly spiced rice and meats. These dishes are served with different sauces that are perfect compliments to the combination of phyllo, rice and meats. I make sure that whenever I am in San Francisco for business or pleasure and with whomever I am with, I have to have at least one meal at Jannah.
author: C B.

description: I honestly dont understand how this place has such nice reviews. We went on a Thursday night when it wasn't even crowded and the service was very SLOW and our food took FOREVER. When we finally got our food it was not only COLD but also had very small portions for extremely EXPENSIVE prices. oh...and the food was DID NOT TASTE GOOD at all...
author: Laili A.

description: Came here with my mom before seeing Dirty Dancing.  The food was so tasty and the lady serving us was great.  It did take a bit longer than was expected but we made it in time to see the show.  I will certainly be back to try other dishes.
author: sarah w.

description:
Having driven by this place for ages now without ever taking the time to go in, my sister and I dined there last Wednesday night and were, in a word, IMPRESSED!

Not only was the decor simple and understated yet pleasant and relaxing, but everyone working there was as kind as kind can be. Oh, the food? Incredibly good and dare I say, really inexpensive. On par with other top restaurants and at a fraction of the cost Jannah is one of those hidden gems I will certainly rave about to friends and clients.

Thank you for a brilliant dining experience!
author: Jonathan M.

description: I'm absolutely floored that this restaurant is never packed given the quality of food. Very delicious and flavorful dishes that have a wonderful home-cooked feel. You can't really go wrong with the lamb shank. If you have a gluten sensitivity let them know up front, they are accommodating and knowledgeable.
author: Shireen T.

description:
We made the reservation at 8pm on a Friday.  We were 15 minutes late because it was so difficult to look for a street parking.  It took us over 20 minutes!

When we arrived, there was no one there. We were the only table until our meal done.  Hummm how can they survive even it is so dead on a Friday's night?!???

The restaurant itself was pretty nice.  The atmosphere was romantic.  

The service was good.  They were so friendly, attentive and professional.  

The menu was very simple.  Not too difficult to read.  At first, we wanted to try the BBQ Quail but the waiter suggested to try the Grilled Italian Eggplant.  Since he strongly recommended, we gave it a try.  OMG, it was so good.  The pomegranate sauce was very unique and flavorful.  Definitely my favorite dish of the night.

The vegetable pizza (middle eastern version) was very unique too.  There were a lot of ingredient in it.  The presentation maybe not that good but the taste was very special.  Very flavorful

For tikka kabab, we got chicken and beef with rice, fresh vegetables, and  tabsee. (Caramelized onion, red bell, eggplant, and curry in tomato sauce) - Again, it was good too.  Everything was so fresh.  The sauce was flavorful.  I did not try the beef but my friend said the beef was better than chicken. To me I think the chicken was a little bit dry.  

Although the food isn't cheap but it is definitely worth it, especially when you want something unique and different!
author: Liza T.

description: It wasn't bad, a bit pricy for what you got. Not a lot of flavor in the Biriyani dish
author: Nick D.

description:
This review is for when Jannah catered for my company.

The Muhamara and Hummus were nothing special, pretty typical for pita.
Chicken well was well spiced but a little too chewy. I appreciated the vegetables hint of mustard; that was nice touch. Salmon tasted smoky, not in a good way.
The dark horse in all this was the Kelecha an Iraqi snack converted to ravioli stuffed with dates, cardamom, cinnamon and topped with yogurt, walnuts, and parmesan cheese. This is crazy good -- a great hodgepodge of flavors.

Given that the yelp page has two dollar symbols, I probably wouldn't go to this place since I don't think it justifies the cost.
author: Eric T.

description: Jannah is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  The food is unlike anything I've ever had before and I LOVE IT!  The owner and wait staff are so kind and accommodating.  I recommend the eggplant with the pomegranate sauce.
author: Adele W.

description:
From other reviews, it looks like some of their dishes are pretty solid. Our company got lunch catering from here, which only included the pizza. So if you're interested in getting other things here, this review doesn't apply.

As for the pizza, I tried the Safeehat Urook (vegetarian) and the Safeehat Falafel. The first was similar to what you'd expect when you think pizza: a thick and hearty crust, cheese, and vegetable toppings. Even though it looked like pizza, it didn't really taste like pizza. That's not to say it was bad, it was just unexpected. I'd give it around 3.5 stars. The second was way different, the crust was made out of the same mixture used in falafels and it was topped with more middle-eastern vegetables and some feta cheese. This one tasted nothing like pizza, even though it looked (somewhat) like it.

For both of these, I'd say the individual components tasted fine but the way they were put together was kind of questionable. I'd give this place another shot if I was nearby, but I'd certainly not get the pizza. I've been looking for a solid falafel place, and I haven't found any yet in SF.

One more thing - a lot of people at work were rather surprised with the meat "pizzas", which didn't have any cheese. There was some complaint that they were poorly named, as the end result was very different from what they were expecting.
author: Amaresh S.

description: Delicious!  Great service, too.  Huge portions, reasonable prices.  The salad that accompanied the kabobs was fantastic.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
GREAT spot for large parties. Very good food, very reasonable prices, and great service. Very nice ambiance as well, I think it'd be a nice date spot. Strictly on food, I might give it a 4.5 stars (I round down as my convention), but for large groups, this was a fabulous spot.

I made a reservation for 12 people two days in advance. We were able to expand that up to 16 the morning of. Waffa (sp?) was my point of contact and made sure I knew how things were going down. We got a fixed price meal for $25 a head, not counting tip, gratuity, or alcohol. Alcohol was also very reasonable at $5 a glass for wine, so that was flowing pretty smoothly.

There is no Healthy SF surcharge and they actually do not have an automatic gratuity for large parties. I asked Waffa to put 18% on the final bill just to simplify things and to make sure no one stiffed them on tip.

Given the prices we were quoted, I was pretty surprised at how nice the venue is. Cute, clean spot. Besides us, it wasn't too packed (I'd say around 75% capacity, with us taking up roughly a third of the available floor space). I was never bothered by any crowd noise, although the other patrons around our table might have disagreed. I think on a typical night, it'd be a quiet, nice place to eat with a special someone without dropping a ton of money.

Once most of our party was seated, they brought out  the first course: flattened falafel (almost like a pizza), burnt eggplant in pomegranate sauce, a mixed hummus plate, pitas, and a sweet ravioli-like plate. Second course came in: roasted chicken, mint salad with salmon, phyllo-wrapped chicken in apricot sauce, and phyllo-wrapped lamb and rice in pomegranate sauce. I wasn't a fan of everything, but I LOVED a lot of it (the eggplant, the falafel, and the phyllo dishes were my favorite). We had something for everyone and came away with a LOT of food. Very, very reasonable.

They also brought out a cake we had bought earlier after they cleared the table and charged no additional cake fee.

They also were very accommodating when it came time to pay. We ended up paying with a wad of cash and 8 different cards, and they were more than happy to deal with all of it.

All in all, great experience. Very reasonable prices, great food, great service, and nice atmosphere. We started planning this party last minute about 3 days beforehand and I couldn't be happier with the way it worked out.
author: David C.

description:
Remember that little hole in the wall Yaya's in the Financial District? Well it's back at a sit down lunch and dinner restaurant and it's just as good if not better but missing their classic shawerma and falafal wraps, which were to die for. 

Bring back the falafal and shawerma and stop trying to be all bougie by not serving "street food."

Anyhoo, the food is still great though to be honest my perdaplow could have used a tiny bit more salt.

Also the owners are these adorable Iraqis. You screwed their country Americans, the least you can do is give them your business.
author: Free P.

description:
I am a USF student. And I went to Jannah to try something new and its so close to campus (like 80 steps away) I had the a phyllo dish with chicken. IT WAS DELICIOUS. It was a little pricy but it is worth every penny. 

I also met the owner Yaya. He is the nicest man!! 

He told me that he is going to be having happy hours now. So I will be back for that. He said there would be $3 micro-brewed beers!
author: Raquel B.

description:
I am not sure whats is going on with this place -- its empty. Always empty... 

Dinner was good. we had kebabs. 

Came here with gf after B2B and as always this place is empty. That day they had special kebab wrap. I asked if they can make just kebab and not wrap it in rice and lavash. Chef came out and said sorry - kitchen is EXTREMELY busy. I was shocked -- they had only 1 tabe seated there beside us... I wonder what they were busy with?
author: Anelya S.

description: This place has the best lamb. Meddi plate was delicious. Service was very nice. Highly recommend!
author: Jay Z.

description: The falafel pizza, soup, hummus, and sambosak were all very good and the people are very friendly and responsive.
author: Tim H.

description:
Dined here last night. I must say everything was so quick and easy. Parking was abundant, either in front of the restaurant or across the street at the grocery store. The service was prompt. We ordered the lamb shank with plenty of vegetables and the Kuzi. Although, I was taken aback at how SWEET the sauce was. It was almost like a syrup. 
OMG and if you are looking for REAL coffee, order the turkish coffee after dinner. It's as large as a shot of espresso, but packs more of a punch, and is packed with tons of cardamom. 
Overall the portions are well sized and fantastically priced. 
I can't wait to return to try the other dishes!!
author: Betsy S.

description:
Sunday night was my fourth time at Jannah in the past couple of years and again I was a little surprised how quiet it was. Four of us got there at around 6:30 without a reservation and sat where we wanted. I grew up in the Bay Area and now live in Seattle and have had some great meals. We have some great dining in the Northwest but I have not been to any place that serves Middle Eastern cuisine like Jannah. The California influences come through with interesting flavors and sauces. 

We had the lentil bulgar salad and an eggplant with pomegranate mollasas vegatable dish that was so good we all about lost it. One of our party scored serious points with his girlfriend by bringing her some of the eggplant. The eggplant stuffed with lamb was excellent and the Yaha's Dolmas were fantastic. The Muhamara dip went great with the pita and fresh Iraqi bread. The Kuzi (phyllo dough filled with lamb, rice, almonds, raisins and spices) was also great.

The people, the food, the relaxed feel of Jannah makes it a place I will continue to tell all my friends about, foodies or not. It is a place you want to go with friends so that you can experience as many new flavors as possible while you share your dishes with each other.
author: Paul S.

description: Tasty food and great costumer service . This is the only restaurant in Bay Area SF has a unique men from  middle eastern food
author: Ali A.

description:
This was a great find! We love Mediterranean food, and this one had some special offerings.  Plus the service was great and the prices were reasonable. Baklava was spectacular!
(Note, I am writing this review 2 weeks after I ate here, and now I'm back in Rhode Island and very sad I can't go to Jannah again!)
author: Christine R.

description: Glad to find this incarnation of YaYa after having enjoyed it when it was on Irving years ago. So far all I've tried was the kuzi and it has left me ready to return at the next opportunity to try other unique delicacies on the menu.
author: Debra M.

description:
I am not a lamb person at all. I came in for their hummus / babagonush (eggplant in hummus) / falafel & pita bread. Honestly I haven't gotten much further than trying appetizers cuz it fills me up!

I've brought friends & colleagues here & some people just aren't into the flavors of the dishes. But don't let their personal tastes deter you from trying this place! It definitely hit home w my veggie friends though!

The owner always gives me extra pita bread at no charge. I always get the falafel pizza without cheese. Sometimes I add a scoop of hummus or babagonush & its like having a veggie loaded falafel in your mouth w every bite!

If nothing else, try their healthy appetizers, chill w a glass of wine after work. Who doesn't like pita bread & hummus?  Better than the usual fried chicken wings for happy hour! If you like the food, consider ordering dinner, otherwise no harm, no foul.
author: Diana L.

description: This place is delicious! I'm not sure why more people don't go to it. It might be because it's not trendy looking. But the food is some of the most delicious authentic Middle Eastern food I've ever eaten in this country, the service is really good, the wine pour is heavy, and the prices are great. Fantastic!
author: Tabitha L.

description:
Good service and nice ambiance... Would even work for a date!

Falafel pizza is very good, Mezze plate was alright also. Pretty good number of options for vegetarians or Vegans
author: Setu U.

description: This little family run restaurant is a hidden gem. The Persapulao and the lamb shank are my favourites. All the desserts are made in-house (including the baklava) and it shows in the quality. I am not a fan of rose water flavoured desserts, however the ones here have such a delicate flavour that elevates the dish to a whole new level.
author: Sumer A.

description:
We came for my dad's birthday. Delicious food - my favorite was the mama ganoush (baba ganoush, mama ganoush, and all the little ganoushes)  and this one dish that came in phylo dough with lamb, rice, veggies and some pomegranate sauce. Wow.  The Dolmas were seriously the best I have ever had, and I am part Armenian, so that is saying something. 

Very attentive service - they actually served a cake we brought from a bakery and didn't charge, even though I offered. Our server even sang happy birthday to my father in English and then in Arabic, at our request. 

I had read many reviews mentioning that the place was empty, but there were four or five other tables when we got there, and by the time we finished, the place was 3/4 full. This made for a nice environment to talk and share our meal. Not too noisy, but friendly and warm. 

The only item I didn't think was perfect was the felafel pizza. It wasn't yucky, just not as amazing as the other items. Seriously, I am thinking about digging into those left overs right now. 

We had six people, and we had wine, coffee, appetizers, five entrees, and it was less than 30.00 a person with tax and tip.  Very reasonable prices and unique food. We will be back.
author: Carla G.

description: The best way to describe Yaya's cuisine is eclectic Iraqi! Known Iraqi dishes but with a twist. What is referred to as pizza is only in the structure not the ingredients, so a falafel pizza is a crust made of falafel topped with veggies and goat cheese; very yummy! Quzi is a must (ground lamb and spices wrapped in a flakey filo dough and delicious pomegranate sauce on the side. The dolma is nothing like the Greek dolma you expect; you gotta try it to believe it, it's amazing! The okra lamb shank stew is the Iraqi national dish and Yaya makes it amazing! This place makes food nirvana. Will be back to try all the other creations.
author: Dhar J.

description:
Jannah is a fairly unknown restaurant in the area but boasts good cuisine and atmosphere with much lower prices than you would expect.  

Pros:
1. Good variety of cuisine including seafood and vegetarian options.  
2. Very clean restaurant and somewhere between formal and casual.  I have been here many times and seen people from jeans and t shirts to people in full suits.  Neither have seemed out of place in anyway.  
3. For a sit down restaurant with good food, good atmosphere, and good service the prices are unbeatable. 

I have nothing negative to say about this restaurant, and I have been here around ten times.  Bottom line, this is a great and affordable sit down restaurant as long as you are in the mood to try something new and a little different.
author: Jason H.

description: OMG this place is amazing!! Absolutely delish mezza: carrot tamarind, turnip pomagranite and a roasted red bell pepper cumin walnut dip!! Entre were kuzi, a lamb pie with raisins and spices-OMG AMAZEBALLS!! and lamb stuffed eggplant with rice. Everything was so good! Definitely coming back!!
author: A D.

description: This is a great restaurant.  The food is excellent and the prices are great considering that the quality is superb and the portions generation enough to share. I especially like the appetizer dips, soups and salmon but everything I've had is very good. The seasoning is complex and unique, unexpected and well-balanced but not so heavy to distract from the high quality of the ingredients. The service is warm, welcoming and prompt. The dining area is very spacious, clean, calm and quiet for San Francisco-- a little formal & old fashioned with white table clothes but charming, spacious and relaxing. Solid wine & beer list but no mixed drinks. Deserts are amazing, but it is hard to save room for them.
author: Danielle H.

description:
YUM!! Let me just start by saying their wines by the glass are $5 so that is awesome!
I had the chicken kabob with the mixed greens and my man had the chicken/lamb kabob with hummus.
Both dishes were amazing!! TONS of fresh yummy veggies and the chicken was  probably the best grilled/seasoned chicken I can ever remember eating. They also have a dinning couch area in the back corner that would be perfect for a large group. Super affordable yummy food with a great classy atmosphere
author: Deja B.

description:
We had come to the de Young but had an hour to kill so decided to find a place to eat.  Glad we decided on this place.  Very cozy place for dates and it's good enough for groups.

The meza selection was good and everything we ordered was pretty good.  Typically I don't like tabule at restaurants since I make it better than most.  But in this case, it was pretty good.  I also had the lamb soup which needed salt but that was pretty good as well.  My husband ordered falafel.  At first I thought it was a wrong order as the waitress brought it to the table.  It looked like a pizza.  I took a bite to taste and ended up eating 2 slices.  They actually bake it so you don't taste any oil.  What a great idea!  I'm going to bake it at home to see if I can recreate what they did so well.

The only thing that I wasn't very happy with was the waitress.  She seemed unfriendly and was a bit slow.  Although the bathrooms were clean, they are very tight.

I will come back to try more on the menu.
author: Diane C.

description:
kuzi - lamb was good..but it was wayyyy too sweet..it's quite heavy..it has rice and wrapped in phyllo..lots of pomegranate sauce..so it's tart and sweet..

the salmon tikka with salad was huge..the salmon didn't have much taste..i think it's more grilled than anything..the vinaigrette was eh.. 

the bread and dipping sauce was good..
author: Minerva L.

description:
I found this venue on Yelp, so it is only fair that I return to Yelp to warn future patrons.

I was looking for a venue for a large party for my rehearsal dinner and I came across Jannah. After exchanging emails with the owner, I asked that they please put me down for a reservation and I said that I would confirm closer to the day. This was about a month and a half ago. Two weeks before my event, I emailed them to say that I needed to cancel my reservation. To which I received this response:

"but you have made a  formal reservation, and I did not take any reservation for that night
and now you are telling me you are now 
do you think is that fair"

Apart from the poor grammar and lack of punctuation, I was astounded to see such an unprofessional email. First off, I told them that I would confirm the reservation later and they had never told me when they needed to know by. Second, I have talked to over a dozen restaurants and they have all told me that reservations needed to be cancelled within 48-72 hours, which is fair. Having given Jannah TWO WEEKS NOTICE, and still receiving an email like this is completely ridiculous. Not to mention that if they do not think they can fill their restaurant within two weeks they have other problems to deal with.

So consider this a warning for anyone thinking about planning an event here. If you are looking to be treated with zero professionalism and respect, Jannah is the place for you. Otherwise, I would advise you take your business elsewhere.
author: Grace T.

description: We've eaten here many times, both for lunch and dinner, and have always been amazed at the high quality and interesting variety of the foods offered. Our personal favorites include all the kebabs, which are always cooked perfectly, along with the dips, grape leaves, fattoosh and many of the stuffed philo dough specialties. It's also a really good deal!
author: John P.

description: I have been here a handful of times. Great food for a decent price. The food is very tasty and portion size is large. I would recommend for a large group.
author: Max H.

description: Wasn't dazzled, but it did the job.  Had the lunch filo pastry - which is like a huge filo dough meat pie.  The service was so-so.  The food was okay.  Wish the portion on the filo pastry was a little larger, or it came with some sides.
author: Joel Z.

description: The absolute best. Perfect serivce, ideal environment, perfect prices, and INCREDIBLE food.
author: Ashur B.

description: Amazing food, amazing service. Simply a great place to eat middle eastern food. Must Try
author: Zahra F.

description: Had dinner at Jannah on Friday with friends and highly recommend this restaurant. The food was Iraqi and absolutely delicious. Everything was fresh and unusual. The kebabs were extremely tender, and the lamb shank superb. For the more adventurous there were authentic native dishes with beautifully seasoned flavors. We brought our own red wine but the Pinot Gris they offered was very good.  The service was extremely warm and welcoming...it's a family run restaurant so you feel like you are dining with a gracious aunt.  This restaurant is appropriate for singles as well as larger groups (we were six) and the good news was that we could actually hear each other talk. Give this neighborhood, white table clothed restaurant a try...it's well worth it.
author: Donna H.

description:
I adore this place. It's cheap, delicious, and serves its fantastic kebabs with the most delicious assortment of vegetable pickles you could desire. The hummus is wonderful, as is the lentil soup, as are the dolmas. I look forward to eating my way through the menu. Bonus: I have celiac, and they are helpful about steering me toward gluten free items on the menu (most of the menu is safe to eat.)

I wish they would advertise better, though. I was in the neighborhood for almost two years before I realized that they were actually *open*. I think putting a sign or something outside might help. But I'll just be happy that there's a delightful neighborhood restaurant that I can always get a great table at and I don't have to worry about getting a migraine in.
author: Photo D.

description: The food here in this neighborhood eatery is so good.  Prices for the lunch menu are quite reasonable.  The food provides a many layered nuance of flavors.  I particularly leaned towards the items with lamb.  Will definitely go back.
author: Bill E.

description:
YAY for YaYa!
We were there several days ago for a private party buffet of 40+ people.  Mr. Yahya Salih himself, and his team, were there to greet us when we arrived.  In fact, Mr. Salih cooked for us. The food was plentiful, super delicious and everyone was sooo hospitable.  We truly felt like we were their guests - not just customers.  And, in case your are wondering - no one in our party knows these folks.  We were not special - or related.  The hummus and baba ganoush were deliciously homemade - the hummus was sprinkled with za'atar and a little olive oil.  And the Kuzi... OMG - it was amazing.
