This is shredded cooked lamb mixed with rice, spices, fruit and nuts which is then encased in phyllo dough and baked. Then it is served with a sauce that i think is made with pomegranate molasses.  It was so good.  I think this alone would be worth a visit.    Of course there was pita bread, middle eastern salad, stuffed grape leaves and both grilled salmon and chicken kabobs.  We were also treated to real rice pilaf and a sauce made from caramelized onions, eggplant, roasted red peppers, garlic and other spices. I guess you could think of this as a Persian ratatouille.  In short - this is authentic Persian home cooking. Mr. Salih is a restaurant luminary in SF and his restaurant is worthy of our patronage.  And - as an extra bonus - the prices are actually reasonable.  Mesopotamian cuisine is among the oldest in the world dating back some 10,000 years.  Once you eat here, you will see why we continue to enjoy it to this day.  Do your self a favor and just go there.  The restrooms accommodate 2 people each and there are no steps.  All is very clean.  The restaurant appears small - but they can actually accommodate close to 130 people +/-,  including the heated patio.  There is on-street parking which did not seem too challenging when we were there.  This place is good for groups and special for celebrations.  These folks do not skimp on the food and repeatedly urged us to enjoy more and more - not matter how much we ate. 2 people in our group had some dietary issues.  They were accommodated with not even a quiet murmur of inconvenience. This is restaurant hospitality the way it should be.  The fact that it is complimented by really good food is priceless.  Enjoy!
author: Barbara B.

description:
On a lunch break, I decided to use a saved Groupon, and try this restaurant. The ambiance was very impressive. If you like exotic places, and good food, I suggest you try this place anytime. I imagine it becomes more alive in the evening. 

Main Meal: 

Safeehat Urook (Organic Cracked wheat Pizza dough): Topped with Mozzarella cheese, tomato and oregano sauce, onion tomato, mushroom, roasted red bell, and Basterma (Middle Eastern Lamb Sausage). & Lentil Soup Soup of the day. (see pictures)

Dessert: 

Kahi  (See pictures) 

Warm buttery heavy cream inside a warm flaky tart served with a warm raspberry puree. Heavenly!! The best! Lo Maximo!

Kahi: (Hot) Phyllo dough stuffed with Kemar (Whipping cream with cardamom) surrounded With Raspberry puree. 5.00

Homemade juices $2
   
  Sun dried lime
  Raisin with mint,
  Pomegranate
  Arabic iced tea
 
Hot drink $2
 
 Arabic hot tea
 Fresh Mint tea
 Regular coffee
 Arabic coffee(concentrated with cardamom),
Turkish coffee(made by the order with cardamom,
author: Ana S.

description:
Its not packed so you can really enjoy a nice relaxing dinner, where you can hear everyone without screaming and without feeling pressure to leave.  I like that. Always a table available without making reservations. I like that too. 

Excellent baba ghanoush, salmon kebab and vegetarian options.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Never heard of this place until I got the Groupon.  And I come to find out Poleng is closed????  (OK, wrong review)

The falafal pizza was the only thing that drew me to buy the Groupon.  I had to try it and it was delicious!  My only gripe was that it was sooo oily.  My BF got the Scallop Maklooba and I got the Vegetarian Tageen.  Both were really tasty and something I've never had before.  

The decor was nice, kinda like the Venetian in Vegas, hehe.  And the service was also OK; I think they're a bunch of kids who go to USF.  They were very attentive but didn't feel very authentic in a Middle Eastern restaurant.
author: Rosalind S.

description: Really nice home style Iraqi food. We went in on a Friday night and it was surprisingly quiet there. The food, however, was really delicious and wholesome. Try their falafel pizza, its really good! The grilled meat skewers are also done well.
author: Mustansir M.

description: We love this place.  Consistently great food with amazing and unique flavors.  Service is very good and the ambiance is nice with traditional music playing in the background.
author: April M.

description:
We have been following Ya-Ya's cuisine around SF since 1993. No kidding. Because when you find food that you love, you will follow it. I was hesitant to write a review because then everyone in the Bay Area would know about my favorite hidden gem. But hey... sharing is caring!

We always start with the Mezza appetizer - a selection of three marvelous tasting dips. My favorite entree is Mom's Dolmas. Nothing like it. Other restaurants serve dolmas cold, but Jannah's dolmas are served as a hot entree with a delicious tamarind sauce. It's so good, you feel compelled to lick the plate. Another favorite entree is the lamb shank. The portions are very generous. Everything about Jannah is consistent, especially the food.
author: Leslie L.

description: Everything was really fresh and good. An adorable husband and wife team runs this place and made us feel very much at home.
author: Morris R.

description:
Went here Friday night at 8pm with 8 people and no reservation.  It was no problem! 

Read that again.  Friday 8pm, 8ppl, no problem.  Then 4 of our friends showed up.  It was still no problem.  The extremely friendly staff brought over another 4 top to the side of our table.  

We ordered family style.  A large selection of dips, apps, and entrees.  Everything was good.  Excellent vegetarian options.  The eggplant was delicious, falafel pizza, and starter platter too.  

Good local draft beer selection too.
author: B B.

description:
Jannah is a neighborhood restaurant with middle eastern fare. What is great about this restaurant is that it is a very large space, so if you need a value restaurant for a large group, come here, as it's not packed. 

However, I wasn't very hungry and was not too impressed with my food. However, I'll probably try to get a kebab or something more popular next time.
author: Shang S.

description:
My GF and I were looking for a quick bite before I took her to the airport...and found Jannah, which happens to be right around the corner. 

We read the other Yelp reviews and they are partly right. Yes, this place is oddly empty for how good it is and no the lamb is not as bad as people say. Maybe Kabob style it dries out, but I had it int he stuffed eggplant dish and it was really tasty. 

The lentil soup and Iraqi Ravioli's were really good.  The Beef kabob was good, a bit dry, and the rice and eggplant it came with was awesome! 

The staff was incredibly nice and attentive. 

Dessert was good and We will definitely be coming back.
author: Daniel D.

description:
I absolutely LOVE this place - it is one of my favorite restaurants in the city - I keep hoping that it will stay open forever - go check it out if you haven't already.

Jannah has your basic Mediterranean staples - hummus, baba ghanoush (sp?), dolma, etc. - but it also has some unique items that I haven't had anywhere else.  The service is always impeccable - and the place is usually pretty quiet - esp. for dinner - it is easy to converse with your companion.  They have great deals on wine too - I think a glass of the house wine is about $4.

They have these entrees that are basically phyllo dough stuffed with a variety of ingredients - e.g. lamb, slivers of nuts, raisins, etc. and then surrounded all around the plate by a sauce - one has an apricot sauce, another has a distinctive berry sauce - those dishes are so good - filling but extremely tasty!

I've also come in here many times when I am feeling under the weather for one of their soups and a cup of steaming fresh mint tea - with the actual fresh mint leaves - soooo good - and really hits the spot when you are congested.  At those times I ask for extra broth on the soup, and they are happy to oblige.

All in all, a delightful find in the city and one that I would recommend to anyone - I've had many special meals here since it opened!
author: Kimberly K.

description:
This place is one of a kind! I don't understand why there isn't a full house every night. You don't even need reservations. 
The location is nice and quiet. The lightening is casually nicely light not bright but not too dim. It defiantly has a Arabian feel with traditional seating as an option. I have come hear many times and it is always spotless and ready for guest. I thoroughly enjoy when they project Arabic music videos on the screen. the environment is really interesting because it suits everything from a family to a large group of friends to a intimate date. 
The menu has its Arabic name along with a brief but informing description. Defiantly affordable! 
As soon as you sit down you are serviced with water and menus. The waiters are always on task with checking in and making sure everything is up to your needs. Then when your ready and have ordered they are prompt with getting your order quickly and to your liking. 
What makes this restaurant stand out is the food and personable service. They have even created there very own falafel pizza. 
Take your time here and enjoy the scenery and food.
author: Lara H.

description: My favorite gem in San Francisco!!! Jannah has amazing food, great service and I never leave disappointed.
author: Emily L.

description: Great service, great food, good portions, nice atmosphere.  Went here last night with my date.  Not many people were there, but talking to the lovely friendly waitress she told us that when is busy it is very busy, but they have slow nights too.  I had the lamb shank, and it was so tender and tasty.  Good wine portions too.  I'm glad that this restaurant is in the neighborhood.
author: Julian C.

description:
Jannah was a truly outstanding meal, served by warm and friendly people ... in a space that was nearly deserted on a Saturday night. If this restaurant were on, say, Valencia, it would be packed every evening. In its slightly obscure location, I fear for its future.

The food is delicious and has an interesting, complex mix of flavors. The only thing that wasn't bursting with deliciousness was the Middle Eastern pizza....the crust was too thick (it's made with chickpeas) and had a weird consistency.

But these were awwwwesome:

Mama Ghanooge
Muhamara
Fesenjoon
Kuzi 
Maskoof

Just writing about this meal makes me want to go back! Yum.
author: sarah b.

description:
Amazing for groups. We had a surprise party, everyone paid $20 and ate incredible food til we were bursting. 

I will say that if you're allergic to dairy, be careful. They tried so hard to steer me clear of the dairy dishes, but somewhere along the line they got it wrong and I was in pain for a bit. If you're not allergic to dairy, this place rocks.
author: Kate G.

description:
OK, are you interested in finding out the meaning of  "Middle Eastern California Cuisine?"  

Oh, yeah.  Sunday afternoon we walked in, and the place was nearly empty.  We were given extra attention this afternoon.  The chef came out to explain which aspects of the food were middle eastern, and which aspects of the food were "California cuisine," as developed when he was working with Jeremiah Tower.  

Let's have a look at it.  The menu items are spelled phonetically, so it helps if you read them out loud.  You will recognize some of them, like the chicken tikka that I ordered.  It featured thick pieces of chicken breast with a very nice touch of  something like tarragon.  It was complemented with a cucumber salad, hummus, tabouleh, pickled vegetables, and lavash.  

Then there were the dolmas, "the way Mom used to make them."  Well, not my Mom, but my Hot Russian Girl said she recognized them.  Besides the actual dolmas, there were stuffed zucchini, stuffed squash, and a stuffed onion, with lamb being the most outstanding ingredient of the stuffing.  This was all laid out over a sauce that looked at first like a brown sauce, but that turned out to be pomegranate.  

Did I mention the wine?  For about $3 each, we chose a glass of chardonnay and a glass of pinot grigio to balance the entertaining foods that we were discovering.  

My Lady chose Kahi for dessert.  Imagine two 6-inch triangular crepes filled with whipped cream and a hint of cardamon.  We had coffee and tea to go along with that, and to cut the effect of the wine we had with our entrees.  

So, all this must cost a fortune, right?  Not really.  $36.15 + tip was all that this cost, and you can bet we'll be back for more!  "Jannah" means "heaven," and I believe the name is appropriate.  

Welcome to the neighborhood!
author: David D.

description:
Yum...what a gem! 
I've only eaten here for lunch so far and it is fantastic!  The Lamb Burma Chili and Jannah salad are so good. and the Kabab Laffa with chicken is also delicious.  
It's perfect for small or large groups, wonderful ambiance and very friendly staff.  They were fast which was great for a quick lunch, but also not pushy when I wanted to hang for a bit.  It's run by a husband and wife team which definitely adds to the charm.  
Also, don't leave without trying the Kelecha (Iraqi snack converted to ravioli, stuffed with dates, cardemom, cinnamon, and topped with yogurt, walnuts and parmesan cheese)... it is out of this world!  Have it as an app or desert ...and paired with their Turkish coffee... makes my mouth water just thinking about it.
author: Summer S.

description: Delicious food for cheap and great service! Came here with two friends and we enjoyed the experience. Best dishes were the safeehat falfel and the sambosak. Nice to break out of the routine and try something new. Will return!
author: Eliza D.

description:
The falafel (pizza style), biryani (unique), and the kabob combos (tender) were AWESOME! I have been here two times this week. Their service is excellent, the servers are friendly and attentive. The Chef even came out to see if everything was fine. 

The food alone was awesome, unique yet it feels authentic.

I suggest this place to anyone looking for some good Mediterranean food!!
author: mikhael b.

description:
i would have given it 5 stars for the cheap wine ($3 a  glass, awesome!), dessert (between $4-$5), and appetizers( fafalel pizza-$5) and the friendly staff, but i think the food made my stomach hurt. 
A few hours after the meal, i was in so much pain! my stomach hurt sooo bad and i didn't really eat much else during the day.

i live so close by so i was really hoping to like this place.dang, ill have to settle for papalote :p
author: Cicely T.

description: Yummy, yummy.  Everything on the menu is good, and they boast a great wine selection and few beers on tap.  Try the quail as an appetizer.
author: John H.

description:
I've walked by Jannah many times in the last couple of years -- it's in my neighborhood, a short walk away from my place, but for various reasons, I've never been in the place. Probably the main reason is the slightly kitchy appearance of the place from outside -- it seems to be an overly-brightly lit restaurant dominated by a Vegas-style painted seascape on the main wall. Seems to rule out an intimate dining experience... (In addition, truthfully, I'm not a great fan of Middle-Eastern cuisine, so I wasnt drawn in by the food.)

Fast-forward to last Friday evening -- it was late, and my friend & I were out of ideas for food choices (and most of the more reliable destinations were completely full.) We decided to try Jannah as a slightly desparate fallback choice.

When we entered, the place was bustling and active, though not completely full. It took a little while for us to get seated. (There seemed to be some sort of re-configuration of the dining tables involved...) But - after that, we received very attentive, very friendly service. There was a real, genuine sense that they were happy and grateful to have us in their restaurant, and we were warmly welcomed on our first visit. A pleasant surprise for a fairly jaded cynic such as myself. In addition (fortunately) the ambiance was much mellower and less cheezy than appeared from outside.

The waiter explained the fairly bewildering menu, and we opted for some fairly non-controversial choices -- as appetizer, Safeehat Falafel, a sort of falafel pizza, and a  single entree, the Chicken Tikka Kabob. Both dishes were enormous. The Chicken dish was a hearty combination of salad and large hunks of grilled chicken. The single entree was more than enough for both of us, and the place was very reasonably priced. A very good, reliable choice. I'll be back to try some of the more intriguing choices.
author: donal c.

description:
Fabulous Iraqi / pan-middle-eastern restaurant. A real gem of the bay area.

After sampling almost everything on the menu, here are my opinions on the dishes:

Must-haves:
- Kelecha
- Japanese eggplant
- Kuzi
- Kenafa

Very worthwhile:
- Safeehat Falafel
- Yaya's Grape Leaves
- Sambosak
- Vegeterian Maklooba
- Fesenjoon
- Lamb shank with Mensef
- Kahi
- Baklava

If you're in the mood:
- Badengan Parmesan
- Appetizer Dips
- Scallop Maklooba

Avoid:
- Safeehat Urook
- Layallie Baghdad

My full review here: http://extraordinarydiningsf.wordpress.com/2011/03/28/jannah-iraqi-cuisine/
author: Patrick B.

description:
This is written by my seven year old daughter, Samantha: 

It was fine. I don't  requst it for a kid it has ward spices .I diddn't like almost eany of it.It isent so crowed It has nice serves. It looks fancy in there.

by a 7-year-old child 2 grade there daddys acount
author: andrew f.

description:
I can't believe it took my roommate and I a full year living around the corner to stop by and try this place out. We came last night and were both thrilled with the service, prices, and of course, the food.

We had two glasses of wine, the grape leaves and the Kuzi Lamb (!) as well as the garbanzo crust pizza. Overall super tasty. We were both pretty pleased with how reasonable the meals were. I paid the same as if I'd gotten a burrito at the place next door but for a much more interesting meal!
author: Hillary W.

description:
This place is a total gem. I ordered the lamb dolmas and they were to-die-for. They came out piping hot and beautifully arranged. Lamb can taste a little gamey for me at times, but this dish did not! It was just. SO. GOOD!

On top of the delicious, piping hot food, the service was fantastic. The owner took my order. She was warm and friendly and accommodated my food allergies, paying special attention to all the ingredients (more than I can say for many restaurants). 

Also, the ambience here is really nice. There is a seating area with cushions and an outdoor patio.  I believe they have hookahs too!

This is one of my new favorites. I will be going again and again!!
author: Lauren K.

description:
This was an interesting culinary adventure. The service was very good and the restaurant was well appointed.

The food was quality, but I was not a huge fan of it all.  My favorite main dish was probably the kuzi, but it was still a little too sweet for me. The dolmas were also quite good. 

I did not enjoy the lamb burma as much as I would have hoped. I was thinking there would be bigger pieces of lamb.

The hummus platter was the highlight of our night. The mama ganoush was amazing.  

I would recommend this place if you really want to challenge your taste buds. Or even your taste friends.

Lastly I have to mention desert. You HAVE get the kelecha. One order is good to split between 2 or 3. I want to go back just for this!
author: Dan P.

description:
This place will surprise you.  It's never busy and personally don't know how they stay in business...but their food is amazing.  The food is a little different, but very good.  I would classify is it as mediterranean with a twist.  

Helpful tip:  Parking on the street is awful over there, but what people don't realize is your allowed to park in the Lucky's parking garage across the street.
author: Lindy C.

description: We went with some friends and immediately went back twice.  The owner is a lovely welcoming hostess so you feel like you are home.  The lamb shank was the best I every had...meat fell off the bone and perfectly seasoned.  So generous we took some home.  Looking forward to getting there soon.  And, such a good value.
author: sandra s.

description:
This place is great - TRY IT! Everything we've had here tastes wonderful, and is very fresh.  Don't miss starting with the Muhamara dip and ending with the Baklava - both super delicious. 

Affordable, yummy food, attentive staff + good atmosphere. Bonus - super nice (and beautiful) belly dancer on Saturday nights!
author: Karen J.

description: I'm in love with their dolmas.  Not the usual grape leave ones.  Instead they are delicious vegetables stuffed with a meat/rice mix and surrounded by an addictive pomegranate sauce.  The people that work there are super nice as well.  Nice ambiance.  Great value for what you get.
author: michelle a.

description: The hummus side and lamb dishes were quite good, interesting flavors in the ghanoush varieties, good service, yummy chicken tikka with hummus plate. All around very good Middle Eastern food. I was going to a party nearby so it was convenient, but I wouldn't travel across the city to return. Just very good local place. But it is better than La Med, for sure!
author: Michelle G.

description:
I had a birthday dinner here with around 16 friends in February that went great. I've eaten here with just me and my fiance probably 4 other times. 

We had the place practically to ourselves, which was great and intimate. The service is always good and the food is always good. 

I usually get one of the Kebob combinations. All the meat is excellent. 

The Dolmas are fresh and tasty.

The Garbanzo Crusted pizza (Safeehat Falafel) thing is amazing. We always get that. 

Tabouleh is good.

They have good wine.

On Saturdays they have a wilde belly dancing show.

Go here and enjoy the music and good food. Seriously, it's worth it.
author: Mack L.

description:
I truly love this place. Everything that I have tried there has been delicious, and the people who run the place are sweethearts.

I always like to recommend Jannah to friends if they are going out on a date--dim lighting, nice patio, and, again, delicious food!
author: Cassandra S.

description: Food here is fairly decent. Their dolmas are absolutely to die for. The hummus-like, carrot-based dip was unexpectedly delicious, fairly sweet with hint of smoked parpika. This place actually introduced me to Middle Eastern cuisine, and I have been hooked since then. Their portion is good sized, not too big that makes it look cheap, but not too tiny that leaves you hungry. Dont skip the dessert. Order either Baklava or Mint Tea. Really nice ending to a wonderful meal.
author: Curtis T.

description:
Tried this place out because I am a HUGE fan of middle eastern food / kabobs, but this place wasn't anything special.

The kabobs were a 3, some of the dishes were better (like pizza with a falafel crust), but overall would not make a return trip here
author: Raza M.

description: Grab a quick lunch since we were at the USF campus area. The lamb and rice plate were good, it served quickly being the place almost full for lunch. I also had the eggplant dip and they were good. I have to come back and try the other items in there menu, so much to try if you have time.
author: Antonio E.

description:
I was really wary of this place after having walked by at dinner time literally for months without ever seeing more than one or two parties dining here.  But Alyssa G. had some sort of Groupon thingy for it, so we came, and I enjoyed my lunch.  

I came back with my parents, and although the food was very good, the service was slightly slow.  The servers were pleasant, though, and for once the restaurant was actually semi-filled, so maybe they just weren't used to having to accommodate so many people.  But the looping music videos being projected on the rear wall were too much.  I didn't mind the music itself, but it was literally a six- or seven-song DVD of a particular singer's music videos, so by the end of dinner, I had watched the same stupid videos three or four times.

I'm dinging them almost a star for having wheelchair-inaccessible restrooms.  Yes, a wheelchair may be able to physically fit through the door, but there's no way it could fit in the tiny toilet stall.
author: John S.

description:
To answer the question, "Why is no one eating here!?!" ...

It's the service. The food was fine, great actually. I'm a fan trying different foods and thought the "California Cuisine" flavor was a cool twist to Middle Eastern food (they had "Middle Eastern-style" pizza, ravioli and ratatouille). The food was delicious and the portions are huge! Two people can easily split an entree and an appetizer for under $30. You really get your moneys worth here.

But the service -- the forlorn, despondent service. Food, any food, (especially ethnic food!) is supposed to be exciting and enjoyable for everyone. I mean, if my waiter was super excited about the food his restaurant produced, whether or not he liked every single dish, I sure as heck would be excited to eat that food and come back. 

But our waiter not only acted like he was on heavy sedation meds but remained completely expressionless the entire time. Two in our party asked for suggestions on the safeeha and the phyllo dough entrees. His response? "Well your friends ordered these two so maybe you should get the same." 

Crickets chirping. 

Tumbleweeds blowing.

Really? How about YOUR opinion? How about putting some thought into that suggestion?

In all honesty, he did refill our glasses (eventually) and asked how everything was (from time to time) -- which was good -- but his complete lack of enthusiasm and nonchalance about his job bordered on rudeness. It made the difference between whether or not we tipped him an extra dollar and whether or not we would go on to recommend Jannah for friends.

Food for thought: It's hard to recommend a restaurant with great food and bad service! :(
author: liz c.

description:
After a spur of the moment trip to the city, I joined some gfs that had dinner plans at Jannah.  I decided to join them, not knowing anything about where we would be dining.  This was my first Middle Eastern dining experience and I was pleasantly surprised by Jannah's offerings.

Our group ordered a few of the dips - each were $3 which seemed very reasonable.  We got hummus, MamaGanoush (sp?) and a turnip puree... all were yummy.  We also ordered the vegetarian falafel pizza for an appetizer.  It was all good food to share and went well with the $3/glass wine.  You can't beat that price!

Most of us ordered phyllo dough entrees - mainly the Sambosak.  Another vegetarian dish.  Also ordered were some chicken and beef kebabs and the vegetarian ratatouille.  Everyone really enjoyed their food though there was one slight mixup with the ratatouille dish... the waitress brought out something that just didn't seem right, my friend called it out and they immediately swapped the dish with the correct item.  We have no idea what it was that she was given originally but they were quick to correct their mistake.  

Some people have mentioned lighting in their reviews.  It did seem bright when we first got there, but they seemed to have dimmed the lights a bit as the evening progressed.  They also turned up the heat a bit as a couple of people at our group mentioned it was too cold at the table.  The servers were very attentive and my drink was never low.  Always a good sign!

The food was delicious, the price was good - I would probably go back and try some new things again.  This may have also opened the door for me for middle eastern cuisine.

Oh and the website seems to be for their old location, however it looked like it had most of the items that were from this new site.  If you search it online it should list the San Francisco address in connection with the webpage.
author: Christine N.

description:
Jannah is a delicious work in progress.  In what is now a large, sparsely decorated room with too-bright lights and too much noise, long-time Bay Area chef de cuisine Ya Ya is in the process of creating a peaceful coastal garden setting that will transport diners from the gritty Western Addition to somewhere along the Mediterranean seaside.

No stranger to the SF food scene, Ya Ya is once again putting out some amazing dishes.  Standout appetizers include safeehat falafel (a delicious Mediterranean "pizza" with a crispy garbanzo bean crust topped with goat cheese, tomato, onion, pesto, and eggplant), delicate and tasty barbecued quail on hummus, and jannah (pickled vegetables), as well as old standbys like baba ganoush (roasted eggplant mashed and mixed with various seasonings).

Entrees also do not disappoint.  The housemade Swiss chard dolmas are unlike any others you've ever tried -- tender, sweet, slightly citrusy, and just plain good.  The hands-down favorite was fesanjoon (chicken marinated in pomegranate molasses), which sounds odd, but is truly to-die-for.

Service was friendly and attentive.  Water and wine glasses were never empty, and dishes arrived promptly.  There are some great beers on tap, including the local IPA from 21st Amendment, and the wine list, while short, was very reasonably priced.

While Ya Ya's work in process is not yet finished, don't wait; run to Jannah today for some authentic, delicious Mediterranean food.
author: CJ G.

description: Excellent neighborhood spot, some of the best middle eastern food I've had in the city.
author: C O.

description:
I was sad that Poleng Restaurant is now gone, but Jannah is a nice addition to the neighborhood. Something unique and when you step inside, it IS different . Dim lighting, a painted sky, pillowy seating area near a wall that projected a cultural music video, a bar, and hookah is the back patio! 

- Bread with some type of olive oil infused dip with spices. Delish! I couldn't stop eating this and even had seconds. 

- Tikka Kabob ($9): Your choice of meat (lamb, chicken, beef, or salmon) and sides (3 different options). I got the chicken (marinated in tarragon) with the side that included rice w/vermicelli, fresh vegetables, and eggplant ratatouille caramelized onion, red bell pepper in tomato sauce. I remember that the sauce didn't taste quite right and there was something bitter to it. Other than the sauce, the flavor in the meat was delish and I loved all the vegetables.  

- Salmon marinated in dill and the side that included hummus, tabouleh, onions with sumac, pickles, tomato, salata, and  lavash bread. I'm not much of a fan of dill, but the salmon was moist and the hummus was great. 

Service was efficient and quick, not crowded during dinner time when we went on a weekend. I remember  we inquired about hookah and the nice lady (owner?) did not hesitate to give us a tour of the patio and mentioned that they have various hours and we were welcome to partake after dinner if we wanted to. One thing that was pretty annoying was the lights in the restaurant kept on flickering here and there throughout our meal, but I still enjoyed the food and atmosphere.
author: Tracy T.

description: The food here is extraordinary! They have some unusual Iraki dishes which combine sweet and spicy flavors.  Nothing on the menu disappointed us. They have a lovely outdoor patio and the indoor seating is cozy. Chef Yaya has created some great Arab and Eastern Med dishes. I can't wait to go up. We ran into this place by chance after exploring the U of SF campus and its gardens.
author: ColomboArgentino C.

description: I am happy to finally have a middle eastern option in NOPA. I am a big fan of the salmon kebabs. I am surprised that the restaurant is usually empty, but then again, I often get my food to-go. Oh, and the Mama Ganoush is great... pomegranite and Baba Ganoush. Sooo tasty. They also have a decent selection of beers on draft (21st Amendment, Speakeasy etc)
author: sam h.

description: Went to this lovely restaurant for the first time tonight and had wonderful wine and amazing appetizers.  But, the best was the belly dancer, Stasha who wowed us with her famous candelabra dance.  She is not only gorgeous and incredibly adept, but also brave!  The dance was beautiful and she was wonderful.  She also danced again, sans lit candles, and chatted with the customers and got many up to dance.  She's very personable and beautiful and we're looking forward to going back.  The food is amazing, atmosphere very nice and the staff are awesome!  Be sure to come on Saturday nights which will be Stasha's regular nights from now on!  She is not to be missed, and neither is the wonderful food!
author: Norah M.

description:
How come no one is eating here?!!!

The food is GREAT, the prices are CHEAP and they have lots of wine and beers (did I mention cheap?).

All the apps are very good: hummus, dips, etc. pita is super plain but that was fine with me. I loved the 'pizzas' the falafal one with pesto and meat was amazing. The sesame dipping sauce for the bread was just ok.

The lamb shank (we had #3) dinner came with lots of rice and was full of flavor. I tried my sister's chicken kabob and it was very good as well. The phyllo dough dishes are huge - one giant pastry wrapped thing of goodness: full of meat, spices, etc. YUM YUM

The staff were great to our group of 12, I would highly recommend this place and can't wait to go back and try more things.

Come on PEOPLE, get out to Jannah!
author: Jessica L.

description: Remarkably good food at remarkably good prices. Attractive restaurant.  Friendly service.  Very highly recommended.
author: John M.

description: Good food and plenty of it.  $5 glasses of wine.  Good neighborhood spot.
author: Virginia T.

description:
I love this restaurant!!! Cannot go wrong with the delicious food, really nice staff, and family ran. 
We just had my last minute b-day cele here and it was awesome with hookahs, plenty of room for our large group, and family style entrees. 
I definitely recommend the Falafel pizzas which I either start with or have as part of my meal, the Tikka kabobs, and Maskoof (smoked trout) but really you cannot go wrong with any of there dishes. They also surprisingly have a great beer and wine selection and all priced reasonably. I only wish it was here when I was a student at USF, could of used there food to go in between classes. 

The food is consistently exceptional.  The service is always good.  We  frequent Jannah for a satisfying meal.  What a fantastic neighborhood gem!! 

(Parking is not bad especially if you get there before Albertson's closes...free validated parking)
author: Bridgid M.

description: Pomegranate sauce with smoke grilled eggplant was great. Rest of the dishes are good too.
author: Balu V.

description:
I walk by this place and it's always dead. Strange since next door is always busy and the food here is good!

The service is attentive and they took my order right away so that's always a plus.  Decent wine selection and  typical modern decor with Ikea lighting hanging from the ceiling.

Got the lentil soup and Tikka Kabob with Lamb and Chicken.  The food was fresh and came out quick and tasted great.   The Turkish coffee was ok.  Not the best Turkish coffee I've had but decent.  

They also have hookahs out on the back patio so I'll have to come back and check that and other food out.  I was sitting by the wall with mural and could people walking up stairs in the building next door but that's probably because it was really quiet.  One of the few places that you can have a conversation over dinner!

Reasonable prices and good solid Indian food.  Not really a destination spot but worth checking out if you live in the hood or are in the area.

If you drive and can't find parking, there is a garage across the street.  If you buy something small at Fulton Market (Lucky's) and have them validate for something like 2 hours, for free.
author: Bryan D.

description: We ordered a Chicken and Lamb kabob dish with Middle Eastern salad.  The meat was tender and juicy.  The dips were amazing-- we ordered Muhammara and Zuzu- truly amazing and never had these dips before-- apparently a unique creation of the chef.  Parking is an issue as is common in SF.
author: Arnab C.

description:
Great to see these guys in a new location.  I used to go to Yaya's on Lombard and was sad to see them move.

The chickpea crust pizza is really interesting and good.  Great starter.  Sambosak is also tasty.
author: Kumar D.

description:
so close to the De Young Museum.  So delish...with every dish.
Tastes that were so new and delightful.
author: patti r.

description:
This amazing restaurant (located right next to another amazing restaurant--Papalote) served one of the most satisfying dinners I've had in a long time. For overall price, service, location and most importantly quality of food, I would recommend Jannah to anyone looking for a delicious meal for lunch or dinner. If you were one of the lucky (or smart) folks who jumped on that Groupon deal, you'll be happy you did. 

We ordered hummus and the Safeehat Falafel to start. The hummus was a work of art in itself with something red sprinkled on top (cayenne pepper, perhaps?) and beets placed on the side. The pita bread was the softest I've ever had. The Safeehat Falafel was so delicious that I wanted to just order two more of them instead of an entree. After all, at $5 a plate why wouldn't you go nuts with their little pizzas? Delicious flavor and packed with lots of veggies and feta cheese. For the main course we shared the Dolmas which is stuffed eggplant wrapped in Swiss chard. Stuffed with what? Who cares, it was awesome. But it was swimming in a plate of delicious tamarind sauce that you can't help sopping up with the rest of the pita bread. The presentation of each dish was beautiful and appetizing. 

Service was great and though I'm not sure if that was because we got there before the dinner rush (around 6:00 on a Thursday) we still had the nicest and most considerate waiter who came around frequently to make sure we were satisfied with the food. 

If you're STILL unsure of whether or not to give Jannah a chance, let me end with this: I stuffed myself with an extra basket of pita bread just to get every last bit of that hummus and tamarind sauce. Walking out with an uncomfortable stomach cramp was never so worthwhile.
author: Emiko T.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!  The food is so fresh, healthy and delicious, and the price is unbelievably inexpensive for such quality and exotic flavors.  I take my team from work there every quarter and we all wish we had this restaurant in our neighborhood!  The salmon kebobs are the best I have ever had, and the Jannah salad is super flavorful.  You can park fairly easily or park at Safeway  across the street and do a little shopping. 
Don't forget the mint tea! One of the best restaurants in the city IMHO.
author: joanne m.

description:
Jannah is a hidden gem. The Middle Eastern food here is excellent, the restaurant is lovely, and the service is fun and friendly. I needed an affordable, delicious place for a graduation dinner for 50 people from SF State, and this place really, really delivered. 

Before I found Jannah, I checked out dozens of places around the city. I'm a big foodie, and I also like to host a good event, so I took this task pretty seriously.  It was very difficult to find places willing to accommodate a group of 50 without renting out the restaurant, which we could not afford. The few places I found in our price range ($25-35 per person) had mixed reviews for big group reservations, or were in Chinatown (difficult driving and parking from Daly City area on a Friday evening). I visited several restaurants to talk to the owners in person, and as soon as I met Yahya and his wife, who run the restaurant, I knew this was a great place. They had several microbrews on tap, plus wines by the glass for only $5. We talked about options for hosting our large group, and I asked tons of nit-picky questions about their Middle Eastern (Iraqi) dishes. We made an agreement for a 3-course, family style meal for an excellent per person price (around $30 per person, before tax, tip, and alcohol). And this restaurant offers free parking at the lucky store across the street until 10 pm. Awesome. 

On the evening of the dinner, our boisterous group of 50 arrived at the restaurant. The restaurant has a great long wooden bar, nice for hanging out. The chef was ready with mezze dishes right away- tabouleh, baba ganoush, a falafel pizza-type dish, sweet ravioli dish, roasted eggplant- and the servers just kept bringing out food. The chef then sent out dishes of phyllo dough wrapped around rice, lamb and apricots, and another with phyllo around rice, chicken, and pomograte. After every course, the staff kept telling us, "Now save some room, there's lots more coming out!" which was funny and so true. The main courses were large family-style plates of mixed greens with hearty portions of grilled salmon, chicken and beef on top. All of the dishes were great, and some were really excellent, like the phyllo, lamb and rice dish. The waitstaff did a great job keeping up with drink orders and even squeezing in my professor who showed up late. The chef/ owner was willing to accommodate one guest's nut allergy, and also made a great phyllo vegetarian entree for our veggie friends. Even when the guests started to get pretty rambunctious after a few drinks, the owners treated us kindly. 

This restaurant is fantastic for large groups. The food was so tasty, parking was easy, and the owners were honest, kind, and great to do business with. I will definitely be back to Jannah again. Thanks for a wonderful graduation dinner, Jannah!
author: C J.

description:
Middle Eastern delights on Fulton Street?! You heard right. On this unassuming stretch in NOPA, blue skies (well, the walls are painted that way), flavorful falafel and mesquite grilled kebabs await. 

Start with a few dips -- the hummas* and  baba ghanooge are well spiced -- and so is the mama ghanooge, which is a sauce consisting of carrots and tamarind. 
 
Lamb goes with this sort of cuisines like cereal does to milk, and the Yuzi is a perfect example. It's a big "block" of phyllo dough, filled with shredded lamb  rice, almonds, raisins, cinnamon, and then served over a rich pomegranate-rosemary sauce.

It's a shame, really, that the restaurant doesn't get more visibility, because the food is really up there, and at very reasonable prices. Chef Yahyah knows he's onto something special, and if you're smart, you'll read this review and go eat some of what I like to call his "culinary,edible, anything but crude oil." 

*I'm using the spellings off of their menu, which I take it our authentically colloquial.
author: Nish N.

description:
This is probably my favorite place to go during my lunch break for several reasons (other than proximity to work/school): 
-Fairly inexpensive 
-Delicious food 
-Pretty healthy menu 
-Good selection of beer/ wine 
-Never too crowded (during lunch hours) 
-Great service 
-Hookah 

So far I've only had a few items, but they were all very tasty and relatively healthy. I find that it's difficult these days to eat out and actually order something that is actually good for you and still satisfies your craving. Jannah definitely brings this to the table. Literally! 

Jannah's Middle Eastern dishes and appetizers that I can pleasantly account for: 

-Hummus (haven't had better humus) 
-Baba Ghanoush 
-Dolmas 
-Hearty Mediterranean Mixed Greens with Lamb and Chicken Kebabs 
-Falafel pizza (made with chick pea crust).
author: Ray V.

description:
I LOVE this place!  The food here is so yummy, good quality, family owned and very friendly.
favorite dish:
Scallop Maklooba 
(upside down) layer of cooked scallop in curry, grilled (eggplant, zucchini, and cauliflower), and rice, surrounded with sabzee (puree of fresh herbs, spinach and tomato) sauce.
author: Emie L.

description:
Pros:  Cute dining room, sky painted on ceiling, huge projection screen to watch whatever events on, prices are not exorbitant, spreads are scrumptious, salads are great and plentiful.  I really liked yaya's grape leaves.  The lamb tikka kabobs are very good...the meat is not minced like other places, but it is also inconsistent.  Some pieces were perfect, some were overdone and chewy.

Cons:  Although the servers are cute in a bright-eyed-bushy-tailed "awww, you remind me of ME in college" way, their inexperience makes the dining experience a bit awkward.  The lamb shank with okra was yuck.  No subtlety, no spice, just slimy, tomatoey, lamb and rice.  The ravioli is not only sweet but very hard.  It tasted awful.  

I'd go for the apps and the kabobs. Stay away from the lamb shanks.
author: A S.

description: Nice neighborhood place.  Friendly staff.  Food is a bit hit or miss.  The chicken we had was great.  The lamb on the other hand was dry and tough.
author: Andrew C.

description: Regrettably, I have to give this place a bad rating after getting sick from the food now twice and today I could not eat much of it and still managed to feel a little sick from it, when I ate some of the food last, for dinner a day or to ago I happened to feel a bit noshers and throw up some of my meal, today I was a little less hungry so I decided to inspect the food a little more and I noticed it didn't smell as good as it should smell, and I could only stomach a little bit of the meal before I threw the rest away
author: Rachel N.

description:
Jannah is a NOPA gem and always delivers quality, reasonably priced food.

I recommend starting with the Safeehat Urook which is a Middle Eastern version of pizza with various vegetables, lamb sausage and an amazing oregano tomato sauce. The beef and chicken tikka kabobs are both great and the tabsee that comes with the #2 option is fantastic.

Don't rely on the website as the menu and prices are out of date. The crowd is hit or miss, but the service is friendly and attentive and maintains a family run atmosphere. Jannah is also good for takeout orders.
author: Chris S.

description:
I really, really want to love this place because it's so close to my apartment, but in comparison to other comparably priced Middle Eastern spots in the city it's just okay. And that's, well, okay. 

The food was okay. The service was okay. The wine was okay. 

Will I go back? Yes, because I bought the groupon like everyone else here in the city. And ya know what? I'm okay with that. A casual setting with average tasting food isn't always a bad thing.
author: Kate P.

description: I am amazed by the food in this restaurant. It is run by the owners, husband cooks and the wife is in the dining room. I cannot emphasize how much I enjoyed the quality and flavors that I had. The hummus and baba ganoush are a must have.
author: Nantas S.

description: The place is kind of cute but was totally empty on a Thursday night. The dolma entree was good. Our server was very friendly.
author: m t.

description:
Word, why is there no one eating here???

This food is AWESOME, and the service is really friendly! Their phyllo dough dishes are great--I've tried the Fesenjoon (chicken, rice, other things in phyllo dough with pomegranate sauce), the Biriani, and Kuzi, and each of them had a very distinct collection of incredible Mediterranean flavors. Their pomegranate juice is legitimate--it makes Pom taste like watered down syrup. The portions are perfect and sizeable, and our bill was great considering the nice atmosphere and quality food. So happy to have this in the neighborhood!
author: Justin M.

description:
Sitting in between Papalotes and Poleng lounge, Jannah adds another unique restaurant to this little neighborhood.  

The kabob combo is delicious and I still can't stop thinking about the hummas.  Prices are really decent.  I have to come back and try the hookah that everybody raves about.
author: Danny P.

description: Food & service was good. Not a bad place for vegetarians.
author: Milana R.

description: Sometimes you just want to go to a place that's relaxed, spacious, no hype, no wait. This is it. The prices are amazing. My smoky and delicious salmon kebab skewer was smoky and amazing. The hummus was yummy. The waitress was nice. No rush, no pretension. Go!
author: Andrew K.

description:
We came here on the spur of the moment-What a pleasant little find! The food was excellent, the portions were enormous, the service was fantastic and friendly, the ambiance was appropriate, the wine list was good and and overall the restaurant and the wine were extremely affordable, especially when considering the great overall quality of the food and service. Best of all there was no trouble getting a table without a reservation on a Saturday night at 8 o'clock.  Surely, once word gets out that there is tasty new kid on the block serving high quality food at a bargain, the crowds will follow.

Located on an uninspiring section of Fulton street, across from the modern Albertsons/ Condo complex, the decor inside is warm, simple and open, and the tables are quite spread out-a rarity in San Francisco.  Due to its spaciousness, there was no bumping elbows with the table next to us or having to worry that others could be listening in on the details of our private conversation.  On the far back wall, there was a large movie screen, quietly spilling out tasteful and culturally relevant music videos from the eastern Mediterranean, easing the transition to the Middle-East and helping to warm our palates for the tasty Mediterranean feast that followed. 

We tried the mini falafel pizza as an appetizer. It was an unusual twist on a familiar treat and perfect for sharing between two to three people.  Another anomaly for SF was the very affordable wine list.  We didn't  order a bottle of wine but thought that the Summer Estates wine by the glass was a bargain at 4 bucks a glass! It's nice to find a restaurant that doesn't overcharge for a descent glass of wine!

It was challenging to choose only two entrees from the array of tasty options, but our friendly waiter, David, was extremely helpful and successfully navigated us through the large menu.  I ordered a delicious filo stuffed pie dish that was stuffed with beef, raisins, cinnamon and spices, served with a tasty yogurt sauce.  It was yummy: both savory and lightly sweet.  My friend ordered a huge platter of skewered chicken, accompanied by an assortment of typical Mediterranean side dishes, like creamy hummus and fresh tabbouleh. The skewered chicken pieces were titanic, extremely moist and bursting with flavor.  Although I didn't order it,  I was also tempted by the lamb stuffed eggplant ordered by the couple at a nearby table. It was covered in a tomato based sauce, and it looked and smelled delicious.  Amazingly, all the entrees were only $13 and gigantic! 

Be warned, you might consider ordering just one entree to split between two people, along with a couple appetizers, or avoiding the appetizers altogether, since the portions were so large.  This would be a great restaurant to come to with a large group or extended family, due to the portion sizes, and affordability - No busted budgets here for a night out with friends or family! Overall, I left feeling stuffed and very satisfied!  I'll definitely be returning!
author: Juan F.

description:
I wanted to try something new in the neighborhood, so I yelped this place and it looked like it deserved a chance.

I called up and ordered a bunch of stuff, including a falafel pizza, hummus, lentil soup, grape leaves, and the salmon kabobs. I have to say the food was pretty good. The falafel pizza was defiantly different, but in a yummy way. They used the chickpea filler as the crust, and then put veggies and a bit of cheese on top. It was so interesting I had to eat the entire thing. Their hummus was ok, the grape leaves were good, but I didn't care for the lentil soup. 

Their salmon was wonderful and it really stood out to me; it had a wonderfully smokey flavor to it and came very well cooked. I was really impressed at how well it was cooked, it's texture and taste. 

What I couldn't figure out is why this place was totally empty. It's a HUGE place by SF standards, and the cooks obviously knows what they are doing. All I can figure is that it's staffed by young kids (maybe SF college kids?) who didn't appear to have a lot of serving experience and didn't really fit the vibe of this place. I mean when I walked in I literally didn't see anyone for almost 5 minutes as I sat at the empty bar and waited for someone, anyone, to come out to help me. But when the kid did come out, he did help me before vanishing again for another 5 minutes in the back until he reappeared with my food. 

In a service oriented city like SF, I think if this place had better service this place would explode. It has the good food, it just needs everything else that goes along with it!
author: Erik B.

description: Jannah is one of our favorite restaurants in SF.  Fabulous food, courteous friendly service, always has space.  This is a family-run restaurant - the kind we like to support in SF - so come try it!
author: Kathryn S.

description:
My GF and I love this place. The food is consistently great - especially the chicken kebab, lentil soup, and the slightly offbeat falafel pizza. Portions are generous, so we usually over order and the leftovers keep us going for another day. The space is huge so its easy to get a seat. They've recently improved the ambience with soft purple(!) lighting. Staff are attentive and friendly. One of those places, where you can quickly become a local and get greeted with a handshake from the owner.

Super handy if you live in NOPA, if you don't - the neighbourhood is not the easiest to park in, so make use of Lucky supermarket's handy parking across the road (buy some chewing gum and get 2 hours free).
author: Richard B.

description:
I've always wanted to try this place just because I walk by it every day.  My friends always recommend me but everytime I walk by, there is no one there.

I finally decided to try it after several months of passing by and it was not bad.

Food: 2 stars
The food was not bad, I had the lamb tikka kabab and it was decently seasoned and made medium rare.  It was tender and flavorful.  I also had the kupsee which, as I heard from the neighboring table, is kinda like a Mediterranean pot pie - not sure about that comment.  The dish was delicious with all sorts of seafood inside.

Service: 1 star
Service was really slow even though there weren't that many tables there and the food came really late.  The staff was friendly though.

Ambiance: 1 star
Very plain with some music in the background.

I would give it a try again just to see how the food goes the second time around.
author: Carmen C.

description:
Remember "Ya Ya" on Van Ness? Well, the owner (Ya Ya himself) is the force behind Jannah, a surprisingly inspired middle eastern restaurant near the corner of Fulton and Masonic.

I've given Jannah a pass for almost a year, assuming it was yet another unremarkable hummus-and-felafel outlet. That was a mistake - the menu is actually a real treat with plenty of unusual and interesting choices.

We were utterly delighted with the dips: a turnip spread, a carrot and cardamom dip, and classic mouhamarra. The zaatar is made with fresh thyme and toasted sesame seeds: perfect. We were very happy with the Makloob entree: roasted vegetables atop pilaf surrounded by an interesting and subtle herbal puree. LOVED the date-filled raviolis with walnut/yogurt topping. 

Eating vegetarian off this menu was great; meat-eaters will not be disappointed either. You could easily (and blissfully) drown yourself in appetizer choices long before getting to entrees. In any case you are certainly not going to go broke eating here.

If there was one area of weakness it was that the breads didn't excite. I am a big fan of the ekmek and simit at A La Turka, especially when it comes hot out of the oven. By contrast, the bread here could easily have been packaged from the store. Alas, it's a small quibble in comparison to the great food.

We'll definitely be back!
author: Michael H.

description:
Unfortunately without knowing, we made reservations here on the day the entire restaurant was being occupied by a community group meeting so we were forced to sit in the outside patio by ourselves. Why they didn't tell us before, I dunno. 

We were cold and they nicely offered us a throw blanket but it still made the Junnah dining experience sightly off.

Ordered: 
- Falafel pizza - the only thing that really impressed me so order this
- Most of us got the combo with choice of kebabs (lamb mint was the best) and side dish like rice or hummus
- Perdaplow - heavy due to the filo dough. Didn't care for this much, one bit was enough
- Biriani - wasn't what we thought it'd be

Basically, the staffers were a nice family but the food didn't really impress us.
author: Nicole L.

description: Don't miss stasha Saturday at 8pm! She's the one doing the dancing. OK, if you're a doubter her website is Stashamania. I mean like the food is fabulous all the time, but Stasha rocks. She has so much charisma you just have to like it. There is no better mediterranean food on the planet. Now to find a parking spot, that is a little challenging. But worth the effort I assure you. Romantic spot as well, good for a date.
author: Nelson M.

description:
I'm sorry to give this place a bad review, because I want to like it, but I just can't. The food is OK, and the staff are very nice, however twice we've gone there they are out of things, and the last time they ran out of oysters, and when they didn't come the waitress said they were out and just took them off the bill. No offer of an alternative or anything. Well, thanks for not charging us for food you didn't give us! LOL. 

Maybe in time they will get their act together, but for now the service, while pleasant, is very uneven, and the food is spotty, so we wont be back for a while.
author: Steven G.

description:
This place surprised us, and has quickly shot up to be one of our most recommended locals.

The food itself is very memorable, and, while a little pricey, is more than fair given the huge portions that they provide. We ordered three things off the menu, and were impressed with each. The Baba Ganoush is excellent, and also comes with unlimited pita bread to make it a recommended option. The kebab is also superb, as we had both lamb and chicken which were each excellent. The kebab is served a variety of ways as well, with our selection of choice being the vegetable option that in reality doubles as a surprisingly huge salad.

Overall, this place was quite excellent from every aspect, from the food to the friendly staff, and we will for sure be coming back some day.
author: Sami R.

description:
Jannah is upscale Mediterranean fare, though the prices aren't ridiculous. 

The Safeehat Falafel ("falafel pizza") appetizer was great; it was easily the most unique dish I've had in a while. The falafel makes up the "bread" of the pizza; it's basically one big thin falafel. It's topped with a thin layer of diced vegetables - tomatoes, peppers, onions, and eggplant, as well as pesto and some very tasty feta. 

For my entree I ordered the Maskoof; a "slightly smoked" trout. I love smoked fish in general (it's the jew in me - bring on the bagels with lox!) so I couldn't resist. It was a huge plate of fish, rice, and some kind of rich vegetable sauce.

The trout was good, but my friend did a better job ordering. He ordered lamb in phyllo dough with pomegranate sauce, which looked decadent. I don't eat lamb, but I tried the sauce with some of the tasty house bread and it was great. I need to go back to try one of the other phyllo dough entrees.
author: Adam B.

description:
Ate here for the first time with my family and everyone enjoyed their meal.  We tried almost everything on the menu as there were 5 of us.  Highlights were the falafel pizza, all the tikka (kebab) dishes and the knafe dessert.  The quality was good and the prices were low.  In fact too low.  $3 for glass of wine?!?!  Appetizers were like $4-5.  Entrees $11.  I mean honestly, I felt like pulling them aside and telling them to raise their prices.  

Bottom line, if you like Mediterranean food and you like good quality food at very reasonable prices, you should try this place out.
author: Al K.

description:
I wanted to like this place.  I even picked it out for a friend's birthday.  But there were just too many things that went wrong for me to warrant recommending this restaurant when there are so many other good Middle Eastern spots to eat at in the city.

Food: 3 stars
Edible, but forgetable.  The appetizers were good, and I really did like the unique falafel pizza.  But the entrees were definitely hit or miss with our large party.

My chicken with walnuts and pomegranate sauce was a bit too sweet, the vegetables it came with were on the bland side, and it didn't look that appetizing in general.  I ate it all, and it wasn't a bad tasting dish.  But it was completely underwhelming and definitely didn't do anything to make me want to come back.

A lot of my friends got the scallop dish.  I think there was a 25/75 like-to-dislike ratio here.  Of the like side, they enjoyed the presentation and that the scallops were cooked well (not overdone).  Of the dislike side, they disliked the consistency of the sauce (compared it to Southern-style gravy... like biscuits and gravy), said the scallops were not that flavorful, and the different sweet/savory flavors did not mesh well together.  This dish was inconsistent among those who got it too, as some had a lot of small scallops, some had really large scallops, and some had a mixture of small and large.  One of the dishes was plated extremely poorly compared to the others as the rice looked plopped on instead of the nice cylinder shape like the others.

Service: 1 star
This is where Jannah takes the biggest hit.  And it's not that the service was rude... just that it the servers were very inexperienced and just got so many things wrong for what was supposed to be a special birthday dinner.

Once our large party arrived, we were not given menus and then immediately asked what we wanted to drink and order.  It was a forgiveable oversight, but the mistakes didn't stop here.  Once we were given the menus, it took a while for them to get back with us to take the order.

Our group ordered appetizers for each half of the long table.  One of the eggplant dishes was given to the wrong side and that side inadvertantly ate it leaving the other table side to wonder where there dish went.  Yes, it was partially the fault of the people who ate an appetizer that they did not order.  But with that big a crowd, there are many appetizers ordered and it's a bit expected that the food you ordered would at least be presented to the correct side.

Of course hummus and babganoush were ordered for appetizers, but very, very little pita bread was given out.  And multiple requests for more bread (either pita or the complimentary bread) was ignored.  We ended up eating most of the hummus and babaganoush with a spoon because our bread requests were ignored.

Two of my friends beer orders were brought out incorrectly.  But they kindly corrected that without fuss.  Still, another sign of inexperience.

When the entrees did come out, they were called out by their menu name leaving everyone to scratch their head as to what it actually was.  It would've been so much simpler just to call out their English descriptions like "scallops," "chicken kabob," "shrimp in phyllo," "lamb," etc.

Our water glasses were never refilled throughout the night and no one ever checked up on us throughout the dinner to see if we needed anything (bread!).

It was not a busy night at all and we were the only large party seated, so I don't understand why the service was so abysmal.

Price: 5 stars
This place will not break your budget at all.  And even splitting the birthday girl's meal and getting appetizers & drinks, the tab (with tip) came out to $25/person.

The entrees are $13 a person, appetizers $4-6, and wine is incredibly under-priced ($3 glasses, ~$20 bottles).

Overall: 2 stars
+1 extra star for the free baklava dessert they gave my friend with a candle (though unfortunately it wasn't as good as other places I've been to) and for the very friendly owner coming out to greet us when we left.

I really wanted to like Jannah as I mentioned in the beginning, but unless they get a more trained and experienced waitstaff to improve their service, I don't forsee myself making a return trip.
author: Mercutio k.

description:
Gourmet Iraqi cuisine in da hood!!! When Jannah moved into the 1700 block of Fulton, which has seen a lot of businesses come and go in the last 10 years, I thought, 'eh, another generic Middle Eastern restaurant.' But finally a Groupon persuaded me to give it a try.

Wow!!! The chef here is the well reviewed Yaya who used to cook at an Iraqi restaurant (Yaya) on Van Ness. He is a charming man and great at what he does. Not only does he offer dishes outside the usual repertoire (hummus, baba ghanoush) served at Middle Eastern restaurants in the United States, he puts his own creative, gourmet spin on things.

Jannah is a bit of a vegetarians' paradise. While there is plenty of meat on offer, there were so many veg choices that we will have to return in order to try them all. Dishes are also healthy and reasonably priced.

Everything we had left me with happy food memories:
* Yudhud ghanooge  (turnip with date syrup) The slight tang of turnip contrasted well with the date, which was not overly sweet. My fave!
* Mama ghanooge  (carrot with tamarind) Very unusual flavor. Delicious. 
* Muhamara  (roasted red bell pepper, cumin, and walnuts) A good rendition of this regional favorite that isn't served enough here.
* Kelecha: (Iraqi snack converted to ravioli) stuffed with dates cardamom, cinnamon and topped with yogurt, walnuts and parmesan cheese. Interesting and yummy!
* Vegetarian Makloob: eggplant, mushroom, squash, cauliflower, onions served atop rice and served with a sauce made of pureed herbs and spinach. Fan-freakin'-tastic!!!

Jannah also greets you with an excellent za'atar (thyme/sesame/sumac dip) and bread.

I am already plotting return visits, friends in tow.

BTW, I just read others' reviews about poor ambiance and service. I guess Jannah has fixed these problems because I found the ambiance a bit upscale and very comfortable and the service attentive and very nice.
author: Erica G.

description:
Definitely one of San Francisco's hidden gems.

This is possibly the only place in town you'll get elegant, high-class Persian (Iraqi) food.  There is more to Arabic cuisine than hummus and falafel, and Jannah proves it.  I cook a lot of Arabic food at home and love to order some of the stuffed pastry things at Jannah which I never make because they're too darned much effort.

Yes, it's never full.  This is because the location is odd and service can be somewhat ... hit-or-miss.  But the food is terriffic and well-presented, and exceptionally reasonably priced.  All entrees are $14, even ones with lamb, salmon, or trout.

Recommend dishes: Hudhuh Ganouge, dolmas, Jannah salad, Kuzi, Sambousak,  We haven't had the pizza or the kabobs, or dessert.

IMPORTANT: The prices on the web site are NOT accurate.  They are way out of date.

There's even parking (paid) across the street under the Fulton supermarket.  Recommended for a romantic dinner on a budget, or for a good dinner at 7:30 on a Friday night when you've forgotten to make a reservation anywhere.
author: Josh B.

description:
I have been to this restaurant maybe 5-6 times and every time I go I like to try something new. I have not been disappointed. My favorite is the pizza falafel and I have just recently fell in love with the fesenjun(sp). Its so tasty and slightly sweet too. 
The desserts are pretty fantastic as well. My favorite is the canafe. I can't wait to go back and try more new items on the menu.
I'm not sure why more people don't try this place. its a must and the service is good too.
author: Judy F.

description: I normally like to experiment with food, and I'm glad I tried Jannah the food was so good. I have now been there twice and have not been disappointed. I ordered the chicken and lamb Tikka Kabbob. Both cut of meat where cut to perfection. I will be back this place is now my local favorite.
author: Elizabete Maria T.

description: Such a unique menu with rich semi sweet sauces and plenty of both vegi and meat dishes. Maybe I've never had good middle eastern food before, but I had the kuzi here and it was the best meal I've had since moving to SF in Feb.  Loved it!  Very understated but good service and fantastic food.
author: Kelsey M.

description:
Huge cavernous space -- which I'm sure will fill up soon! Delicious, flavorful dishes. Even the oil accompanying the free bread to start is so thoughtfully seasoned with sesame seeds and lotsa spices. I had the regular dolmas which showcased an eggplant, squash, onion, grape leaves, all of which were stuffed with seasoned rice and lamb. My husband had a phyllo stuffed with chicken and, I think, almond on a bed of apricot-y puree. $11 entrees, $3 glasses of Salmon Creek vino. Well-executed food at college shack prices.

The Magritte-like paint job and stark space can be a little odd but just keep focusing on the food like a good, responsible foodie.
author: enmi k.

description:
Our dear friends were in town and we wanted to go out to dinner to a restaurant serving savory and somewhat exotic food, but  with a quiet enough atmosphere  to allow us to talk and catch up. At Jannah we had a super tasty dinner, the service was attentive but not hovering and we were able to converse freely (without some loudmouth boor or group of screechy women at the next table). I loved the availability of parking across the street...made the evening stress-free! 

I recommend Jannah and will definitely go again.
author: Anne M.

description:
Delicious food, cheap prices ($12 bottle of champagne, not kidding) and hookah? Honestly, can life get any better than this? 

You may find me here on a nice Sunday afternoon, sitting outside on their cute little patio, drinking champagne and smoking hookah, loving the amazing service, and $3-5 appetizers (like the falafel pizza...seriously good stuff). 

Enough said.
author: Hannah L.

description:
I have now come the entirely selfish conclusion that it is a good thing the middle east is constantly in turmoil, else I would eat my way through the entire region.

Jannah makes me love Fulton/Masonic even more, cause I love Papalote and Poleng too.

The "pizzas" are really good, so are the salads, and the oversized filo dough plates, at $11, can't be beat!
author: Lindsay T.

description: Delicious.. Love the decor! Hope this place stays open! My salmon tikka with greens was great, can't wait to go back and try something new!
author: Dana S.

description: We were only in this neighborhood for a concert at nearby USF, and had heard nothing about this lovely restaurant beforehand.  The Middle Eastern cuisine here is really exceptional, much better than other good Middle Eastern places we have enjoyed.  Our party had two of the phyllo dishes (sorry, forget the names of the dishes), and I had one of the lamb shank preparations.  The shank was beautifully done - the meat was very tender and fell off the bone the way this kind of thing should be prepared.  What was really great about everything was the spicing - not over the top, yet very distinctive.  This was so right down to the Arabian coffee with cardamom that I had to finish the meal.  The wine list also looks interesting, with several choices from Lebanon, Turkey and other places in that part of the world.  I expect we'll return (totally worth the drive from Marin) and try a few more things.
author: John C.

description:
I had no idea Yahya Salih was such a San Francisco institution. After our absolutely delicious dinner he told me about his previous restaurants, and reading some other yelps, he clearly has a well deserved following. The man is serving up some seriously delicious food.

In fact there is so much good stuff on the menu, you will want to go with a group. There were five of us, and together we started with the unique garbanzo crust pizza with chicken and barbecued quail on (!) hummus. Both were fantastic.

For mains we split swiss chard dolmas (one of my favorite ever), a lamb kebab platter that included small lavash wraps that we absolutely used to make meditteranean burritos, as well as this incredible phyllo dough stuffed with chicken, rice and raisons that is served swimming in an apricot sauce. As my friend said, it's very apricotty.

But hands down the best dish, and one of my favorites in recent memory, was the pomegranate molasses marinated chicken. Just say that over and over again. Try not to smile. So good. I had three servings, and I would have had three more were there more to be had.

The financial damage for this epic feast? About $20 a person, which included one beer and a bottle of wine. I told Yahya he should raise his prices. This was a steal.

So why only four stars? I'd love to give them another, the food was easily five on it's own, but I wasn't feeling the ambiance too much. It's a large space, so conversations echoed, and there was no music and the lights were on the bright side. Dinner with a group of friends was fine. An important date, not so sure. I'd be doing them a disservice to not mention there is an opportunity to make the place a little more intimate.

Ambiance aside, the food, price and service were exceptional. I hope Yahya's latest endeavorer has a long and prosperous run.
author: Jason B.

description:
I enjoy Southeast Asian and Middle Eastern cuisine for the same reason: the variety of complex flavors found in every dish. Jannah is a pan-Middle Eastern restaurant, with clear influences from typical Moroccan, Persian, and Turkish dishes. 

Their menu has many tempting choices, but my friend and I decided to share the kuzi (phyllo pastry stuffed with meat, almonds, fruit, and more) as well as the fesenjoon (a sweet chicken dish). Both were presented very nicely, and offered a fantastic array of tastes and textures, including pomegranate, walnut, and apricot. I also got a cup of Turkish coffee for 2 bucks, which I enjoyed.

Service was a bit slow and not all that knowledgeable, but still friendly.
author: David Z.

description:
Everything we've had here has been AMAZING.  I work in the area, and after the first time, my husband (who's a chef) and I ate here for lunch 4 more times in the last two weeks.  I've yet to have a mediocre dish.  Especially good: the phyllo dishes, the salmon kebab (tender and moist), baklava, falafel pizza.  Much higher quality than the very decent food at La Mediterranee.

Like others, I'm puzzled as to why neighboring Papalote sees large lunch crowds when Jannah does not.  It's not that much more expensive, particularly with their good lunch specials.  As opposed to Papalote, Jannah's dishes are cooked fresh, and are really what people used to call gourmet.  The people who run it are sweet and meticulous about quality.  I find this in very, very few places in SF.  I hope Jannah starts to get the attention and business it deserves.
author: K O.

description:
I had the chicken tikka with the rice and eggplant option, a hummus appetizer, and the house cab.  The food was very flavorful (the chicken was cooked perfectly, hot and still moist) and I have to say it was the best $3 house wine I've had.  And this was only their second week.

It came out to $34 for a dinner for two.  I'll be back.
author: Rego S.

description: I love Middle Eastern food so when I moved in around the corner I knew it wouldn't be long before I had to stop in. Unfortunately, I'm sorry I did. There was nothing wrong with the place per say, there are just many better options here in SF. The hummus and pita were clearly store bought and my lamb was super gamey - and I love lamb. I thought the whole experience was mediocre and won't be going back.
author: Emily K.

description:
Recently ate here for a larger party and very much enjoyed it. Of course it could have been the great company! 

First, the flavors are different than most middle eastern (ME) places that I've gotten used to.  This is Iraqi ME food and there are some specialties and interpretations that are different than the Western ME foods.  I truly tasted ME foods that felt like the missing evolution between Levantine and Iranian (Persian) cuisine. Some of the Persian sweet and sour and some American fusion thrown in. Try the Perdaplow, Kuzi or Beriani Phyllo dough dishes.

Second, the wine list is very reasonably priced.  I like it when I can afford everything on a wine list and I don't feel I'm being charged more than triple for an average bottle I can get at the grocery store.  The Bekkaa valley Lebanese wine with the French name was excellent! (Funny, I was in the Bekkaa valley in 2000 and real alcohol was not sold blatantly, but non-alcoholic beer was available at some restaurants.)

I did not get to try what I've heard is the most famous dish of Iraq: Masgûf. Masgûf is a fish dish usually cooked in or over a fire for an hour or more adding complex smoky flavors.  I would like to go back to try this because I really liked the flavor of the smoky salmon kebabs we ate that night.

The place was not full.  The staff was attentive and accommodating.  We ate better than desert sheikhs. It might not be what you're used to in terms of the flavors, but this restaurant deserves your attention and support.  It would be a shame to lose this gem in the neighborhood.

In addition, we had two Iraqi natives at our party who said the food here was VERY authentic.  Give it a try.  Give them some feedback and encouragement. And have a glass of wine for me.
author: L B.

description:
i should've done a research on what ingredients they use for the dishes as I don't eat eggplants... almost 80% percent of their dishes come with eggplants.

anyways, the dishes I tried were great! we tried their stuffed ravioli kind of appetizer and or really hit spots.

their kugi was just great.. perfect mixture of sweet and sour.. and other flavors. 

the trout was nicely cooked as well. 

the dessert we tried definitely challenged our pallet; it was hard to tell whether it was a new flavor or just something was missing.

overall, this was a great experience, especially for the modest price tag!
author: Sung C.

description:
Middle Eastern cuisine? I'm busting through your doors. We were in my house mate's old neighbourhood and decided to pay a visit to the latest restaurant in town - and what a great idea that turned out to be. 

We started off with the middle eastern pizza with chicken. Generous toppings packed up close to the edges - nice flavours and texture, although I wasn't won over by it in particular. All my love was saved for the Italian grilled eggplant with pomegranate sauce. Oh, lord, this is what you put me on this earth for - it was like eating a savoury version of marshmallows - very sweet, but completely moreish and perfect in every single way. I rarely get overexcited about food, but this was definitely an exception to the rule. I may have giggled.
