We then shared the smoked trout and the fesenjoon. Personally, I found the smokiness of the trout a little overpowering, but it was cooked beautifully. I loved, loved, loved the fesenjoon as well - crunchy walnuts complimenting the sweetness of chicken and seasoned rice. I had a glass of the Merlot (Salmon Creek -  which slipped down so easily it had to be followed by a second glass). We ordered too much, ate too much and had too much leftover. The price - less than fifty smackaroons. This is fine eating for a budget that befits this day and age.
author: Catriona C.

description:
We ate at Jannah on New Year's Eve with 8 of our friends.  They loved the food and the service and will definitely return.  We had filafel pizza and the mezza plate as appetizers which were superb.  One friend ordered the chicken barley soup and claimed it was the best soup he's had in his life.  You certainly can't beat that review.  
It is a neighborhood restaurant, very reasonably priced and some of the most wonderful spices and herbs that make the food so interesting.  The lamb and rice stuffed grape leaves were also very good.
author: Toby S.

description:
I first came in to Jannah for lunch a few weeks ago with my gf who has been going there for years and years. I too, quickly fell in love with their menu and after a delicious lunch of chunky lamb tikka, salata, hummus and pita-- I knew I had to come back!

SO I dragged the fiance out to Jannah last Friday night after ranting and raving on about it all week. Jannah is a super cute restaurant, that is nice and quiet, fantastic prices -- a perfect spot to catch up for a low key dinner.

With everything on the menu looking so foreign (and delicious), we had to ask the waitress for her recommendations. We started off with the grape leaves (stuffed with rice and sundried tomato) and Kelecha (Iraqi ravioli stuffed with dates cardamom, cinnamon and topped with yogurt, walnuts and parmesan cheese) and... we were BLOWN AWAY! The food here is so flavourful and unique-- if you are a bit of a foodie and love trying out new things, the kelecha combination will leave you speechless.

For our entrees, we opted for the lamb tikka (again), the lamb was super tender, marinated perfectly and is so delish with hummus and salata. We also tried the Vegetarian stuffed eggplant-- if you are an eggplant fan, you will fall in love!

All in all, a wonderful little neighbourhood restaurant that will have you coming back to work your way through the entire menu. Seriously, how often do you look at a menu and think to yourself, there is not a single thing that does not look divine!?

PS-- While prices are still reasonable for dinner, ($14) the lunch menu is a steal at only ($9!!)
author: Shahirah I.

description:
I live on McAllister so this restaurant is only a block away.  I have a persian roommate so of course he was excited when this place opened so close. He said it was just "decent"  but very cheap so a friend and I decided to go.  Well he was right, the food WAS cheap - esp the drinks.  The glass of wine I had was $3 but it actually tasted like $3 dollar wine so that sucked.  It was very vinegary for some odd reason.  The humus was great but they kind of skimp on the pita and you have to ask for more.  The kebob dishes were pretty tasty, i LOVED the eggplant thing it came with.  The place was missing the yogurt cucumber sauce that I love, but then again maybe my knowledge of middle eastern food is lacking and that is only offered at certain places?  

The ambiance of this place was super odd to me too.  You know when  you were little and you wanted to play restaurant?  I felt like thats what it was, a bunch of kids playing restaurant but not necessarily in a bad way.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Jannah's a great addition to the neighborhood, much better than the previous tenant (a rumored business of ill repute). 

Upon sitting we were offered bread and zatar in oil. For appetizers we tried the carrot and the turnip dips, really smooth and tasty. The carrot had a smokiness that was a nice surprise. We also tried one of the pizzas, a falafal crust with veggies and goat cheese on top - terrific. I had the lamb dolma entree, the rolls weren't just stuffed grape leaves, there were also stuffed sections of yellow squash, eggplant and onion, the filling was meaty and well spiced and served warm with a really nice sauce. My husband had 3 phyllo wrapped triangles filled with spinach and other vegetables, it was very nice as well. 

Prices were good, not cheap but worth the quality of food and service. Vegetarians have many options. I'll definitely be going back.
author: Erikake Z.

description:
What I like about this place is: 1) it serves a different cuisine than the "organic, California, fresh" cuisine that many other San Francisco restaurants offer, 2) it's actually good, 3) prices are reasonable and 4) you don't need to make a reservation two weeks in advance to eat there on a Saturday night, or, in fact, need any reservation at all!  No obnoxious wait at 6:45 on a Saturday night.

The Mahamara dip is a definite must - red bell peppers, cumin and walnuts . . it was so good.  We also got:

 -  perdaplow (phyllo dough with shredded chicken, rice, and almonds in an apricot sauce).  This was probably my favorite of the three entrees.  It comes out as a huge round block of phyllo dough swimming in the apricot sauce.  It sort of seemed like it needed some salad or rice on the side, although it does have rice in the filling.

 - fesenjoon (chicken marinated with pomegranate molasses).  This was also good, sort of sweet, and served on a bed of rice and crunchy vegetables, which was a light and refreshing.

 - sheik something or other (eggplant stuffed with lamb and other stuff).  I can't really review this dish well because I'm not a huge fan of lamb.  And this lamb seemed pretty lamb-y.   

Ambiance was acceptable.  The walls are painted with lightly clouded blue skies, and they have a big screen set up in the back showing a woman singing in  . . Arabic maybe?  I have no idea, actually . . . I guess it adds a cultural touch?
author: Jenny R.

description:
New place in the neighborhood so I thought we'd check it out.  We had a lamb pizza appetizer, a chicken/beef tikka kabob entree, a phyllo dough entree filled with lamb and two beers.  The lamb pizza was a thin crust pizza with ground lamb on top.  It was pretty good.  The kabobs were good as well.  I thought the beef was well seasoned and liked that better than the chicken.  The chicken was kind of bland to me, but it was moist and cooked well.  Just not too flavorful.  Rating them against other kabobs, I'd say that they are decent, nothing special though.  You had the option of getting rice or bread with the kabobs. I went with the bread and it came on the side.  The kebabs on the plate were sitting on thin layer of hummus and were surrounded by 6 different sides (cauliflower, pickles, salad, etc.).  The key to note here was that there was no "bad" parts on the kebabs... as in no fat or anything you cut off and put to the side.  The entire thing was just good meat.  My friend enjoyed the phyllo lamb as well.  It was a pretty gamey for lamb, but that's a personal preference. The phyllo dough was sitting on a lot of what I think was mango sauce which wasn't my style, but my friend was scooping it all up so I'll drum that up to preference as well.

The servers and staff were all nice.  They did make a couple of errors like bringing out the appetizer after we got our entrees and bringing the wrong phyllo dough entree (we ordered the chicken and got the lamb instead... yes, we could have sent it back but it was good so we kept it).  It wasn't a big deal when you realize that everything we ordered came out to $33.  That's pretty cheap for a full dinner for two!  As for the decor, it is much nicer than a place that has $11 entrees (every entree is $11).  If I just based the rating on the food, I'd give it 3 stars, but when you factor in the price and atmosphere, it goes up to 4.  I hope this place sticks around.  I'm going to go back and try some of the more adventurous items on the menu.
author: John K.

description: Organized a baby shower here which was PERFECT. The staff was extremely helpful in every respect and they have a wonderful carpetted stage area where my baby was able to crawl around to amuse himself while we were waiting for guests to arrive so it was wonderful. Thumbs up to this place and I will come back over and over again. Seats lots of people and is a great place for large parties. Also, free parking across the street at the supermarket so you never have to worry about parking your car.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Jannah is now on our short list  - especially now that I've found the felafel pizza, definitely my new favorite food of the year AND a good value - paired with a salad, it is a perfect dinner for me!  I also enjoy their lentil soup while my bf always gets a bowl of the chicken barley, which is hearty and tasty.     The hummus is great and while the first time we came and didn't get enough pita, that seems to have been corrected with a generous bread basket when we ordered the same this most recent time. 
My BF loves the kebabs - you get 3 choices for accompaniments.   I had a kebab the first time and hope that I can one day move past the felafel pizza to enjoy  some other entrees, like the curry scallops or any of the yummy sounding phyllo dough treats.

The owner has greeted us both times we've visited.    The waitstaff does seem a little inexperienced, but have performed to our satisfaction and have been really pleasant.
author: Maria C.

description:
The food selection, portions, and price are all fine, but they really need to liven up the decor to make this place "Pop". I knew I was in a Mediterranean restaurant b/c of the cuisine, but decor-wise, nothing.. 

The back patio seating is nice but loose the sterile flood lights in exchange for something...anything that makes it warmer to diners. 

I like the full bar, but again, liven it up. Lighting, candles...something.
author: Miguel O.

description:
Definitely 4 stars, at the least.

We loved the Lamb Saheefa. The Tikka Kabab was not that great, but still pretty darn good. We also had some desert, which was topped with date syrup and cream, it was good.

Last but not least, the waiter was the best we have seen. Wish every waiter was like him.

Will definitely go back sometime.
author: Aussfchi R.

description:
Like several others, I passed by Jannah a bunch of times before giving it a try (thanks, Groupon!). 

It was pretty early for dinner and the restaurant was virtually empty. This can sometimes be kinda awkward, but sitting out on the patio made it seem nicely private instead. Our server was extremely nice and happy to recommend his favorite dishes to us. 

The food: the raisin drink with mint was one of the most bizarre "juices" I've tasted. I'm not sure how I feel about it. The falafel pizza, though? GET IT. Delicious and totally worth $5. The muhumara dip was really good as well. The vegetable maklooba could have been a little warmer, but the sauce was very flavorful and it was a nice portion. 

I will definitely return to try some of the other dishes that piqued my interest: vote yes on middle eastern/California fusion food!
author: Robyn M.

description:
Delicious middle eastern food, cheap not-swill house wine for $3 (you heard me) a glass, pleasant surroundings, graceful, professional service.  What more can you ask for?

Tonight I had the dolmas. In addition to the minced lamb/rice-stuffed grape leaves, as you'd expect, there were also hollowed-out pieces of yellow zucchini, a whole onion, a small whole eggplant, all filled with the same mixture.  A lovely lemony (sumac, I'm guessing) sauce covered it all.  I could barely finish it.  The price?  Eleven bucks.  Amazing.  I had a decent glass of cabernet sauvignon and a lovely entree for under $15.

I love this place, and I hope you will, too.
author: Earline A.

description:
We had an awful experience with this restaurant over the weekend.  Don't host an event here; they cannot manage big parties.    

We attended an event here over the weekend.  The event was reservation-only.  It was full-house for the restaurant.  And there were only 3 wait staff.  We sat for 30 min before our drink orders were taken, and well over two HOURS before our entrees were served.  It was obvious that the restaurant was ill prepared for the crowd.  They gave a table of 2 the same sized appetizer tray as for our table of 10.  And the wait staff was told to ration the falafels, so that each guest can only have 1 piece.  We paid $25 per person (which doesn't include drinks) and didn't have enough to eat!

When we talked to the manager later about the long wait time and not having enough food, and the inequity between a larger table vs. a smaller table when everyone paid the same price, the manager of the restaurant rudely and brusquely dismissed everything, after loudly demanding in our faces "what do you mean not enough food?!!"   

Oh, it gets better.  

If the manager had actually shown that she cared about service and client experience that evening, I wouldn't have rated the restaurant 1 star.  But the manager of the restaurant, probably wife to the owner, acted appallingly.  She was incredibly rude and confrontational.  When we asked if she thought it was OK for her customers to wait for over 2 hours for their entrées, she said dismissively "I'm already saying I'm sorry.  What else do you want me to say?" 

"Are you really the manager?" I asked in utter disbelief at how rude this woman was.  

She actually then proceeded to storm into the kitchen, to get the chef/owner, complaining loudly in the dining area that still had some guests - "She does not believe I'm the manager!".  

Unbelievable.  She caused drama in the restaurant she's managing.  

The dance event was supposed to be a celebration amongst friend and family, and unfortunately our experience with the restaurant's poor planning and management's rude behavior put a damper on it.   

The only up side was our server, who really did tried her best.  We still offered her a good tip (because it really wasn't her fault), but she simply refused to take it because she felt so bad about what we went through.  I wish the restaurant's management can take a lesson on client focus and good service from their own wait staff.   

Suffice to say - we will never return to this restaurant.
author: W L.

description:
A fake middle-eastern restaurant, with food that's not bad but not more than not bad.
The soup and hummus had absolutely no flavor, and the Indian / central-Asian fusion (calling things tikka instead of kebab) doesn't add anything.
For real middle-eastern food, go a couple of blocks southwest to Kan Zaman.
author: Noam R.

description:
At first this place worried me. When we walked in at 7pm, there were no other customers in there. We ordered the hummus and two of us ordered wine to start. The hummus is only $4, which is the right price, because they don't make their own pita bread and barely give you that much hummus. There was actually a hair in our pita bread, and when I pointed it out to the main host (as our waiter had disappeared), he only took away the hummus and brought back a new one (I guess he didn't understand that the problem was the bread?). Then they brought this other type of bread, with an oily-sesame dip, which was good. However, they didn't knock off the ap which I think they should have done because of the hair. It was a big hair (better than a small one?). 

HOWEVER, after this rocky start, it was actually good. I had the vegetarian dolmas, which also included rice-stuffed summer squash and tomatoes. It was huge and had a very good yogurt cream sauce which was delicious.  My two other friends liked their meat dishes (I think they got kebabs) and the rest of the meal went without a hitch.
author: Kennedy K.

description:
I'm a huge fan of this place.  The food is absolutely great and I was pleasantly surprised!!  

We ordered the hummus to start with and it was smooth and creamy with plenty of pita.

 Next up was the quail which is served on hummus (just in case you get the hummus as well) and my fiance said it was out of this world..  And it was two pieces for five bucks..I mean come on...seriously!  My wine was three bucks and it was a tasty pinot.  

Next up was the tabbouleh  and the herbs were very refreshing and they kept the pita coming.

Our entrees were the chicken and beef skewers, rice with vermicelli noodles and  steamed veggies.  It was a lot of food and they gave you plenty of meet.  The steamed veggies could have been salted a little, but the whole dish was clean and very healthy.  

The other entree was the falafel pizza...It was nutty, crunchy and so different than anything we've had.  We loved the different flavors with it. It's a must have if you come to Jannah.

The atmosphere on the other hand is a problem....it's a bit stale and cold and could use some plants and drapes.  It would be nice to have drapes or screens to section the back room off from the front to make the main eating area a little more cozy....and did I mention put some plants in there.  

The wait staff was nice , young and inexperienced but they were trying and you could tell.  

I'm giving them a solid three stars simply for the food.  If the atmosphere was a little warmer they would get a fourth.
author: Lisa Kim J.

description:
I am surprised that this restaurant isn't overflowing.  The food is unusual and every dish is tasty.  They have a flair for making middle eastern dishes that I have never had elsewhere and each one is more tasty than the next.  Their menu is very reasonable and the selection is extensive.  There are many many choices if you are vegetarian.  I really want to see this restaurant succeed.  Parking is easy=either on the street or 2 hours free parking across the street at Lucky's.

RDW
author: Ruth W.

description:
This place is soooooo good. I recommend the Falafel Pizza. 
yum
author: LeAnne C.

description: Mmmm-mmmm-mmmm one of the best dinners I've had in some time and better, one of the finest dining experiences.  All for an excellent price.  The staff was fabulous - extremely friendly and attentive.  The space is beautiful - very modern.  The food was fantastic - I think very authentic Middle Eastern with some delicously exotic dishes.  I'm still dreaming about the Turkish coffee - it was so damn good! Five stars is not enough
author: Rita D.

description:
I really, really liked Jannah, and they will earn a full 5 stars once they get more comfortable and experienced. The food was really delicious, and we had tons of it for so little money (2 apps, 3 main dishes, 2 desserts, and 6 glasses of wine for around $60).  The oysters were so yummy.  There was also this incredible (I wish I knew the name because this won't do it justice, but it's what it was) hot cheese dessert.  The waitstaff was super nice, though the water guy was a little overexcited to fill our glasses after just a sip or two.  Like someone else said, it'll be awesome once the stereo system is set up.  

Support your neighborhood restaurant, and enjoy!
author: Carrie A.

description: great taste of original iraqi style cooking!! i enjoy every time i go thou they dont open enogh you better make sure they open before you show up haha
author: Tam C.

description:
First off great location, easy parking (mostly free) and safe neighborhood.  

Secondly, the prices are reasonable ($3 wine, 3.50 beer), staff is friendly and knowledgeable, plus the clouds painted on the ceiling reminds me of the Venetian in Vegas.

Now I saved the best for last, the food is pretty darn fabulous! Both the authenticity of the flavors and variety of local tastes.  But at these prices we had a couple rounds of drinks enjoyed several appetizers and left more than full.  We will have to try the appetizers next time!

We will be back!
author: Chris M.

description:
OK, so I should say if there were a 3.5 i would do it.  Basically, I love that this little neighborhood is sprouting restaurants and I want them to succeed. We were hesitant to go in because it is always empty but the people walking out the door were in "heaven" from their dining experience so we gave it a shot. 

I had the Kuzi - amazingly delicious, the eggplant appetizer also very very tasty in a way I have never seen eggplant before. Everything else we ate was just fine/ok. 

Service - A+
Cheap - A++ (3 dollar drinks - holler!)

Word of advice if the folks at Jannah are listening - you must immediately stop serving that stale crap you have for bread and get some fresh goods, turn this review into 5 stars right away. I mean that was truly some bad bread and I like to spoil my dinner with restaurant bread, its kind of a tradition especially when dining with my mom, it gets her very annoyed. Also, to establish middle eastern cred - probably should stop using hummus and pita from the grocery store across the street.
author: Erica R.

description:
We went in as a party of 5. The food was horrible. I can understand if 1 person doesn't like the food and the other 4 are happy. However, all 5 of us hated the food absolutely. There was not one redeeming factor. 

The meat was more than a few days old. The food was overly tart. The sauces felt like they were made quite a few days ago. 

For the price they charge, they're very very bad. I'd have given 0 stars if i could have.
author: Meghneel G.

description:
OK, so Jannah hasn't actually opened yet, so this isn't really a review yet, but I'm very excited to have a new Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, Cal-Med place opening up in the neighborhood. It will be a great addition. 

Every time I walk past they are closer to opening up, so perhaps any day now. Please support them!
author: Gucci M.

description:
I was so stoked to get an email that YaYa had opened a new restaurant. I first discovered him and his food in the early 90's on 9th Ave. and have had to discover his new location every time. I didn't call after getting the email. I just finished work and went straight there hoping that Jannah would be the old/new YaYa's. I walked in and smelled the food and the bliss was immediate! I have found YaYa again. 

I had the lamb kebab tikka and it was sublime. But the perdaplow is back as a regular dish on the menu. I'm having that for lunch tomorrow. Jannah is the new venture of YaYa Silah that captures his savory tasty past. If you ever ate and the early YaYa's and miss them you can rejoice! 

YaYa is a man who loves his food and loves to share it. I have talked with him in the restaurants and his love of his customers and craft are evident in his smile and greeting. Yes, it is newly opened. It was very slow as I was in at 5:30 so the service was excellent. I can't speak for when it is busy but give them time. Be patient and give them time. One should try to avoid rushing when eating wonderful food. This is a place to savor the food in.  This is a place to feel comfortable in.  There is no pretense here just great food and an owner who cares.

(If you know of YaYa's in Burlingame forget what you know. Yes, it is the same YaYa but he tried to do something with partners who were more interested in things other than food.)
author: herb m.

description:
I dropped by to get food to go.

The interior is a bit kitche but reminds me of La Turka in the Tenderloin. Its not a great atmospheric dining experience but the really important part...the food, is great.

Since I got my food to go I cannot judge its presentation but the quality of the food is extremely good. Entrees are $11 which isn't cheap considering the casual dining, but I'm pleased the food was even better than I was expecting. 

Once this becomes an established business (and by the food I'm sure it will) I think they should gradually update the decor as I think the food is greater than the dining experience.

If you already like middle eastern food you'll like it, but if you're not familiar with it, this would be a great place to start at a reasonable price.
author: Christian K.

description:
We chose to meet friends at Jannah simply because I had received an Urban Daddy email telling me about Iraqi cuisine in the Western Addition.  The review was complimentary, but certainly did not rave about the restaurant - like I am about to.

We arrived before our friends, so had time to peruse the menu.  It looked good.  Then I turned to the wine list.  Suddenly things looked GREAT!  Wine prices like it was 1988!  I can't remember the last time I saw a good glass of wine for $3.  No really, I wasn't old enough to drink back then.  The wine was a producer called Salmon Creek.  (apparently its a well-known producer's second label for hotels and restaurants, sorry, can't remember who.)  Its really is good wine.  So, do the math... they sold us a bottle for $12.  It any other restaurant it would be twice that amount. (ok, moving on...)

We ordered the large barbecued oysters with goat and feta cheese and herbs.  Simply amazing.  They're not just large, they're HUGE and really good.  $1.75 each.  Also the quail with hummus.  Next time I'd skip the quail, it was..well.. quail-like, small and delicate and a pain to eat.  Really good, just hard to eat.  

For our entrees, we ordered fessenjean, dolmas and chicken tikka.  All good.  All well presented.  The fessenjean was some of the best I've had in the city.  If you've never had it give it a try - it is quite the gastronomical explosion.

The service was also good.  We never had to ask for more water or bread.  When I switched from Sparkling wine to Chardonnay they brought me a fresh glass.  My only small issue is that they served my sparking wine in a standard wine glass.  They also took away the dirty dishes, glasses, etc quickly.  This is a major pet peeve of mine as small tables can quickly become very crowded. 

All in all it was a very good experience.  It would be very good for large groups or parties as there is plenty of room.

As I write this I am wavering over whether to give them a 4 or a 5.  They really deserve a 4.5, but yelp doesn't allow that.
author: Heather C.

description:
Delighted to find the newest version of Yaya's with the food as excellent as it always was, including some new exciting additions like the pizza with a chickpea crust. Like a pizza slapped together with a fallafel sandwich. Couldn't get enough. 

Service, as always, warm and inviting, like being a part of a family dinner party. And then of course, there was the lovely relaxing environment with the signature "Yaya's" Mediterranean blue pendant lights. The entire time we were there, we couldn't stop smiling.
author: Shelley M.

description:
What a treat! Excellent food, beautifully presented, great service and a price!! 
Will go back with friends!
author: Ginny W.

description:
I would like to echo the question, "WHY IS NO ONE EATING HERE?!"

Unfortunately, it's located off the beaten path - but it's definitely worth the little extra effort to get to it.  Cute and quirky atmosphere, friendly staff, and DELICIOUS food.  Everything on the menu looked fabulous; this is the kind of place I need to come back to so I can try all the other items I missed!

I had the Fesenjoon (delicious shredded chicken haloed by rice, tomato, cucumber, and other veggies with a pomegranate sauce drizzled on top).
My boyfriend had the Kuzi (shredded lamb and almonds in a crisp phyllo dough, surrounded by a tart and cinnamon-y sauce).

Generous portions, but not overwhelming.  Prices SUPER reasonable.

The juices are definitely worth trying for something different and refreshing.
I can't recommend this place enough!
author: Anna R.

description: Something different and VERY tasty. We were heading east on Fulton, looking for something to eat with not a lot of time before a show started in the Civic Center ... in other words, we didn't have the ability to be choosy. I saw the sign, Yelp'd it quickly and decided to give it a try. Definite winner! Everything we ate was great ... anything they make inside phyllo dough is worth trying. Our suggestion is to order a bunch of stuff and share it.
author: Fred M.

description: Delicious Arab food, abundant portions, good prices and amazing service! Everytime we've eaten here we've had a wonderful experience and the family oriented atmposphere is icing on the cake! Be sure to look for the painting of little Jannah on the wall by the bar :)
author: Golad C.

description: We love take out from this place.  The carrot hummus is a particular favorite for our kids.
author: Roderick J.

description: Pleasantly surprised by how good the food and atmosphere was here. Went for a birthday evening and had the best time. Food was delicious and the staff were very attentive. I would go there again. Check it out.
author: Danielle D.

description: Well, I definitely know now that Mediterranean food isn't my absolute favorite cuisine, but they had amazing attentive service!
author: Rachelle P.

description:
Overall: 5 stars, because it brought me back to the flavors of my favorite Greek restaurant back home in the Midwest. Yah, this is Californian Middle Eastern, but the flaky, light and crispy phyllo dough pockets of shredded chicken goodness all smothered in pomegranate molasses and crushed pistachios triggered memories from childhood visits to The Parthenon in the Windy City (a must, if you visit Chi-Town). 

Recommended Appetizer: Safeehat Falafel - garbanzo bean crust with goat cheese, tomato, onion, pesto and eggplant - delicious Mediterranean style pizza.

Recommended Main Course: Perdaplow - crispy, golden brown phyllo dough pocket with shredded chicken surround by a lake of raspberry-cinnamon sauce. Golden raisins and almonds with the chicken contrast beautifully with the exotic sauce.

MUST-HAVE Desserts: ??? - ask for cheese cake in a phyllo dough wrapper with raspberry topping. Gooey cheese center with crispy crust and sweet fruity sauce to cut the dairy. Deelish. 

Menu: Jannah appears to be owned by Ya Ya. You can find the menu here: http://www.yayacuisine.com/menu.htm

Environment: If Jannah means "Garden" in Arabic, then I can see how the owners are literally putting together what appears to be a coastal, garden setting. The walls are sky blue and you seriously forget that you're in Nopa, because the interior is so bizarre and new for the neighborhood. 

Nopatite satisfied? YES. Beautifully made dishes and sweet wait staff. Beer is cheap and wonderful when eating so many rich Mediterranean foods. I'm thrilled it's a block from home - will eat again...and again and again.
author: Greg S.

description:
Great food and good prices, nice waiters/waitresses  BUT service can sometimes be really slow. 

Give it a try! I'm normally a tough critic but I support this place for it's amazing food.
author: M R.

description:
I ventured here with Groupon in hand--and realized how the groupon was an attempt to save the restaurant with quality food but empty dining room. Authentic cuisine with ok service, I don't see this little place lasting much longer. 

The food was definitely good, but nothing was "wow" or "amazing". We started with the Babaganoush- a little too much tahini for my liking and would have preferred better pita bread (I don't think this was homemade). I had the lamb pizza and middle eastern salad (with very yummy feta dressing) and the portion size was great. My fellow diners had the phyllo dough koozi and lamb tikka kebab (wow - just realized we are all big lamb eaters!) and everyone was happy.

Even without the groupon this meal would have def been cheap (all the main dishes were only $14 with large portions), I can almost see this place doing better as a more casual order-at-counter place or take-out. Overall, decent place if you are in the mood for middle eastern.
author: Rena Z.

description: This is a wonderful neighborhood gem. I always order their lamb tikka with hummus plate. The lamb is always juicy and cooked just right. Kid friendly too!
author: Leah H.

description: I'm an only child. If you ignore me for 10 min, I get cranky. I'm also a little fat kid trapped in a grown up's body, so good food would've totally made up for it. Alas, your food tasted like I could've cooked it. For reference, I once ruined a can of ready-made Campbell's soup.
author: Janett R.

description: Really good! I recommend the lamb shank with potatoes and onions as well as the mama ganoush.
author: Todd H.

description: Great little neighborhood restaurant. Never really a wait and it ranges from moderately to partially full (thankfully for when you just want to sit an eat!). Prices are fantastic particularly for the appetizers. With a great variety of flavors that are quite unique it is a great alternative to daily mundane food. Interior is kind of funky which makes it more interesting - particularly when they have the belly dancer! Only wonder is why they don't utilize the large bar they have there. With a little decoration and a bartender (and perhaps some glass barriers to keep potential noise from the bar leaking into the dining area) it could be a great place to catch a drink.
author: Dave P.

description: Excellent food and probably the best, friendliest service I've ever had at a restaurant.  I had the Kuzi which was a lamb/rice dish in phyllo.  Perfectly cooked, it was crispy and light on the outside.  The lamb was super tender and juicy with wonderful seasoning.  The pomegranate and apple reduction around the outside was just perfect.  The place was very clean and a cute spot.  Quiet location as well as incredibly fast service.  The service was the best I've ever had.  They genuinely cared that I liked the taste of everything.  they were happy to explain in detail every dish, and to find a good match for what I wanted.
author: S W.

description:
For quite some time now I've walked past Jannah without giving it a chance.  I am quite picky when it comes to Mediterranean/Middle Eastern food.  Bad weather and not wanting to lose my parking space led me to give it a try........ Jannah passed with flying colors.  

Everything tasted fresh and was extremely flavorful.  The Falafel Pizza (Safeehat Falafel)  that everyone raves about on Yelp lived up to the billing.  The Lamb Tikka Kabobs came out a perfect Medium-Rare to Medium and were accompanied by everything pickled (cabbage, garlic cloves, cucumbers, cauliflower...)  For me, a sure sign of freshness was the Tabbouleh salad.  The cucumbers were crisp and the tomatoes firm.

We also tried the Kuzi (phylo dough filled with shredded lamb rice almonds golden raisins allspice cinnamon and ginger served with pomegranate-rosemary sauce).  It was sweeter than the average entree, but delicious nonetheless.

There was also a belly dancer which added an entertaining aspect (though mildly awkward in a small setting).  There is a decent selection of wine by the bottle but very limited by the glass.  I stuck with the Anchor Steam on tap.

Everyone seems to complain about the service.... but what do you want??? When my beer was low I was asked if I wanted another.... when a plate was completed, the plate was removed in a timely manner.... when the meal was done I was asked if I wanted coffee or desert.  I'll take this over a hovering waiter any day.

Prices were very reasonable as well.  An appetizer, two entrees, and 2 pints of beer came out to $40.  I would highly recommend giving Jannah a try next time you're around the panhandle!
author: Adam L.

description: Now I read that alot of reviews complain about service, but the service my friend and I received yesterday was uncalled for. Why? Because it was non-existent?! We arrived at 7:30pm on a Monday (they open from 5pm -10pm EVERYDAY), yet they had their closed sign up. There's nothing to 'pro' about - this place should not false advertise their hours or at least have the common courtesy to explain why they were closed during operating hours.
author: Jay L.

description: I would say 3.5 stars, the service was ok, the prices are not super high. I tried only one dish (which was recommended as their most popular dish), but the sauce it was served with was way too sweet for the dish. Mediterranean  is my home cuisine, so it is not that I do not know how it should be served. Generally I liked the place and might go back, since it is just across my house.
author: Nastia R.

description: I'm at a loss for words. The menu is titillating. The proprietor makes you feel like you're at your favorite uncle's house. The food tastes like it looks and looks like it's in a magazine. And then there's the coffee that's magical for some in an unexpected way...
author: Stephanie C.

description:
ONE HUGE NOTE: CLOSED ON MONDAYS (Why they don't have a sign on their door/online or Why YELP has the wrong time beats me...)

3.5 Stars. This place has very delicious food, but is poorly understaffed. Each waiter/waitress was so nice but the fact that they were constantly running around just trying to meet everyone's needs and their frantic faces really showed how much  more help this place needs. If they had more waitors I think we could notch it up at least another 1/2 star. Mind you they really tried to be of service, just didn't have enough octopus arms to help every single person. It was just chaos waiting to be seated - there was no hostess to even know who was next so they said who's next and whoever raised their hand first got seated. So, that being said...

The food was great! I LOVED the falafel pizza and the lamb phyllo. That phyllo dish is to die for, but alas the kabobs are so plain and mundane. For 1/2 the price, you can get a better kabob within a mile's radius. Whoever recommended the sun dried lime drink must love super sour drinks (this tastes sort of like the sour plum flavor that many Chinese people like... yeck). But to each his own... :) Anyways, I'd go back again but next time I'd try the lamb shank.... the girl who ordered one next to me made me want to eat her plate. Sigh.
author: Jeannette L.

description:
Delicious!
Every dish was amazing. Ask for more bread to sop up the perfect and unique sauces. You're gonna have to share because you'll want to taste everything presented on the table. 
Jannah's is the epitome of why we dine out, extraordinary and interesting food.
Prices are awesome. The wine selection is affordable.
Service can be less than knowledgeable, but the food makes up for it. 
If you're fortunate enough to see the middle eastern man in the chef outfit with smiles from ear to ear you've seen the one and only Yaya.
author: Joe B.

description:
Either we got a bad plate of food or we are horribly ignorant in Middle Eastern cuisine, as this place has averaged 4 stars before my review.

I am not a big fan of Middle Eastern food but decided to eat there on a whim.  It was right next to a Mexican burrito joint and I figured you can eat that anytime.  We walked in and the restaurant was empty.  It was very clean however and we were greeted by the sweetest waitress.  She radiated an aura of sweetness, or maybe it was a field created by some heavenly scent she emitted.  I ordered the lamb something, and the comrade ordered the walnut sweet chicken.  Before the food came, we were given a little basket of bread.  Tasting it, it literally tasted like a hot dog bun.  It was hot dog bun in cube form.  Then the food was presented towards us.  Giving me some of her chicken, it tasted like desert...it was so sweet.  Laughing at her misery, I tried my lamb, and it pretty much had no taste.  The rice was very dry, thus, we basically ate out of politeness because as I said earlier, the waitress was too sweet.  After half an hour of playing and picking with our food, exchanging funny looks, playing footsies, and trying to hide food under our spoon to make...I asked for a box.  I am not the type to complain about food or threaten to send it back--the Gestapo died along with WWII and I do not want the serveurs to serve with a figurative Luger pointed at their heads.  Sometimes you get good food, sometimes you don't-'tis the way of life.  

To end this on a positive note, they have bottles and bottles of wine shelved.  Maybe it would be a good idea to get blasted beforehand, before stuffing your face with hot dog bun bread.  If you see a waitress wearing sketchers, that is the sweet waitress and please tip her more.
author: Brian V.

description: Yummy food and HUGE portions! There's also free parking in the garage across the street. No full bar though.
author: Zrinka D.

description: Overpriced for the quality of the food. Good ambience.
author: Alex L.

description:
This place is highly underrated. There's almost no wait, the food is cheap and good(large portions) and they have very friendly service. 
I'm going to start coming to this place more often. There is an outdoor back patio and hookas to smoke from. The atmosphere here needs to grow because everything else is great, maybe people think it is too formal? But, that is just the culture and style. Nevertheless, it's way better than kan zaman as far as food and service
author: John c.

description:
Food is delicious...
I will definitely try many of their dishes, however,  I won't be eating take out there until they comply with S.F. laws......

**THEY USE STYROFOAM for take outs.....**

Once they go "green" they will get a 5- star
author: J A.

description: Yum! This place is very tasty! I don't know why so many people go to Papalote when they could walk into the next next door and way better food for the same price. The servers are friendly (even helped me pick out food that would be easy to eat when I got my wisdom teeth taken out), the food is mouthwatering, and the prices are great. I'm so glad I live a block away from this place.
author: Andria M.

description: I had Jannah cater my husband's 60th birthday party and I (& our guests) couldn't have been happier. The owners of the restaurant were as sweet and helpful as could be, and discouraged me from over-ordering (since their phyllo pastries are several times larger than the norm). Everything was delicious, especially the baba ganoush and muhamara dips and the chicken, lamb and vegetarian phyllo pastries. They provided all the platters and more pita than I could ever use so that everything was party-ready, and the gentleman insisted on giving me, free of charge, a platter of his signature date-stuffed ravioli to put out as a dessert. I couldn't recommend this business more highly.
author: Delene W.

description: Quite possibly one of SFs best hidden secrets. Don't let the formality of the dining room scare you. The falafel pizza appetizer is unreal. The entrees are all the same price. Try the lamb okra dish and thank me later. A date for two is easily under $50 (excluding drinks).
author: Rocky S.

description: I am from out of town and my friends invited me to Jannah's spur of the moment and it was the best Mediterranean/ Middle Eastern food i have ever had,  along with the lovey service of family members. The whole experience from service to the plated meal was excellent. We had a wonderful time, thank you to everyone at Jannah's!!
author: Brittany R.

description:
I absolutely LOVE this restaurant including the friendly wait staff and owners that make it a pleasurable experience! I don't understand how anyone can give this place any rating other than excellent.  I've been to Jannah multiple times in small parties and large groups of 15 on up and they have always given us excellent service and amazing cuisine!  I've also been to their previous restaurants and Yahya's food is always delicious. Everything on their menu is wonderful. My favorites (hard to limit) are the Maskoof (smoked trout) and the Tikka kabobs, although I have to start with the falafel pizza as well. You can't go wrong with dessert either. The raspberry and phyllo dough Kahi and the slightly crunchy cheesey goodness that is the Kenafa are so good I can't stop eating them until I'm ready to lick the plate clean, which of course I wouldn't do in public, but tempting none the less.

Thanks Jannah for giving me another great reason to come into the city!
author: Sarah C.

description:
This was my third trip to Jannah since this summer. The first trip was funny as there was a power outage just as we had placed our order. They told us the kitchen was down and they spent some time banging away at something on the roof. They were very sweet and apologetic - bough us each a glass of wine and asked us to please come back another time. 
We did. We had a fantastic time!! Not only is the service friendly and fun, the recent upgrades to the ambiance make a huge impact, new lighting and drapes, but the food is really good and very different. 
We started the last time with a yummy Hummus. i had the whole fish which was light and crispy, flavorful and just what I wanted. I can't remember what my friend had but she really loved it. I am not a fan of eggplant normally - but as has been noted in other reviews- the way they do the eggplant is fantastic and makes me want to change my mind about the plant. 
Two days ago we returned for another round of happy. We started with the BBQ'd oysters. They are not kidding, these are some big oysters. They were flavored with feta, goat cheese and herbs. They were unlike anything I have ever had and they were wonderful. Really fantastic. I had the Kuzi. Again it was unlike anything I had ever tried. The lamb and rice wrapped in Phyllo was presented beautifully. The accompanying sauce was unusual and delicious. It was a pomegranate rosemary sauce thickened with corn starch and it gave the dish a very dynamic quality nicely offsetting the appropriate gaminess of the lamb. My friend had the Samosas and enjoyed them immensely. 
This is a restaurant that continues to please me and one to which I will be returning on a regular basis. Be adventurous!! Try something totally new!!
author: Bill G.

description:
After several hookah sessions here, we finally decided to commit to trying the grub full on. Needless to say it was worth the wait. The lamb pizza-feerwhoza something or other was awesome. It's cracked wheat crust was just the right girth, and it was peppered with just the right amount of cheese and sauce to make for a more than adequate lunch. I shared a phyllo cake stuffed with rice, garbanzo beans, almonds fat, meaty shrimp and not too slimy scallops, all bathing in a shallow cinnamon pool of sauce. Previously, we had gotten the burma-not the location but a lamb based chili with lentils, which had a wonderful texture and hearty taste. The dolmas, or yaya's grapes were plump, and flavorful. (Though the nomenclature may be off-putting, the appetizer itself makes up for any visuals of chewing on some old dudes pruney grapes.) 
As for the hookah? It was robust and cheap! $12 dolla. I like the fact that the staff is attentive and always gives extra coals the size of mini boulders. (sorry, Khalid) 
I hope business picks up with the school starting, this is a place that deserves to be filled.
author: Sam N.

description: Excellent food, service and quiet ambience. Go with 4 people to get more choices and share. Reasonable.
author: David T.

description: We had a wonderful meal - the salad/kebob I ordered was generous and tasty.  Service was excellent - (our waiter even demonstrated "French Service" skills - i never see that!)  We were talked in to ordering the dessert - backlava.  A very wise suggestion.  This is my 4th visit to Jannah, and I have never been disappointed.
author: John M.

description: Jannah is one of the most Unique eating experiences that I've ever encountered! YaYa is out of this world with designing dishes and flavors that you have never had before! Try the Falafel (Pizza-style) and PLEASE same room for dessert! and no matter what....have the coffee and ask YaYa to read your coffee "sludge" ---A talent you will find from no other!
author: Rachel M.

description: After writing my glowing review, I had a kind of bad experience here food-wise last Friday night. The dolmas had this weird acidic off flavor, the lamb kebob was pretty dry, and the chicken phyllo dish was a cardamom bomb. Different chef? Off night? I dunno. I'll probably still go back, but  I'm not as enthusiastic as I was.
author: Jessica J.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. I live 2 blocks away and have been anxiously awaiting the opening of a new restaurant in the neighborhood. After the paper was pulled off the windows and the lights were turned on, my enthusiasm dropped a little bit. The place looks cheap and the lights are way too bright for dinner. But the food is really the most important part of a restaurant, and they do takeout, so I still remained hopeful that it would all end for the best.

Last night the remainder of my hope was brutally killed. I read the yelp reviews and saw the vast majority being positive and raving about the food, except for the lone dissenter, who compared the bread to hot dog buns, but I was skeptical of his review as he stated he is not a fan of middle eastern food. I on the other hand am a fan of middle eastern food, and the food at Jannah is just plain horrible. Some of the worst I've eaten in the bay area. I suspect most of the people who have reviewed it here are either friends/family of the restaurant owner, or part of a religions cult that believes food should be used to punish us for our sins.

Our meal started with the complementary bread, and as another yelper mentioned, it tastes kind of like a hot dog bun. But plenty of places skimp on the bread, so I wasn't too put off. We ordered the salad & hummous for starters. The salad was fine, nothing great, but not bad either, it's pretty hard to mess up a salad. Then the hummous came, which was my first real indication that something was going wrong. The hummous was bland and the pita bread wasn't even as good as the stuff you get in a bag at the grocery store.

Finally we ordered our entrees and that's when the train went off the tracks. We ordered the kuzi (lamb wrapped in phylo) and another dish I can't remember the name of, but was pomegranate chichen of some sort. There was nothing good about either of them. First the presentation: they looked like they came straight out of a can of dog food. just a round lump in the middle of the plate. One came on top of a plate of rice with a few (over)steamed vegetables. Then came the taste, really attrocious. The pomegranate chicken was sickly sweet, and the chicken itself was kind of flavorless. I've had pomegranate chicken before at other places and enjoyed it. The other dish was slightly better, but that's not saying much.

The food was so bad we couldn't finish our meal, and that's a rare thing for me, I will eat just about anything.

The one good thing about the place was the staff, they were very nice and the service was just fine. The seem a little inexperienced overall, but made up for that with enthusiasm.

I guess you could say the food is relatively inexpensive, but for what you actually get it's still way overpriced.

If you are looking for Mediterranean/ Middle Eastern food you will have a much better experience at Ziryab on Divisadero, la Mediterranea on Fillmore, or that place on Haight, which I can't remember the name of right now. The prices are about the same, but much better food.

If you just want a good, but inexpensive meal in the neighborhood, go to Papalote, or Green Chile Kitchen, or the Vietnamese place on Hayes & Masonic. Any one of those has better and cheaper food than Jannah.

My last suggestion if you still want to give it a try, just order one entree to start, if you like it you can always order more, but I doubt you will.
author: Fred B.

description:
I am so glad I live in this neighborhood because Jannah is a restaurant I will want to enjoy about once a week, given the exquisite flavors, nutritious mix of offerings, and affordable pricing.

Tonight was my first time. Squeeze and I went on the recommendation of neighbors. We had the falafel pizza, which was eye-poppingly good with feta, tomato, red onion, green onion, and shitake mushroom arranged on a perfection of falafel--rolled-into-pizza-crust.

I had the scallop dish, which is a food-tower architecture that actually works. Perfectly curried scallops in profusion layered over meltingly roasted rounds of mellow, savory eggplant, over roasted cauliflower and zucchini (these alone would pull me back to Jannah!), over  a generous circle of rice, the whole thing surround by a sauce of spinach and mideast spices that work mouth-wateringly in combination with the plate's ingredients.

Squeeze had the combo with lamb and hummus, tabbouleh, salad, pickled onion and veg, and some super-hot little yummy peppers. As others have mentioned, the lamb was sophisticated and flavorful and not OLD. Squeeze said this was the first tabbouleh he's actually *liked*. All others are bitter or have bad dressing or both.

But I haven't mentioned one of the true geniuses of this place...

Pita and lavash breads that are fluffly and light and delicious all on their own! Honestly, I usually think of pita and lavash as papery/cardboardy substances that are only useful to convey stuff that's more edible and desirable. Again, I could feel the pull to return to Jannah just for the lavash.

Mint tea with dessert was fresh mint leaves doused with boiling water. Yummmmm.

As for price, entrees are all $13. Dishes of beautiful dips like hummus are only $4. I could imagine being charged double for my scallop entree at some inflated-ego place.

We are eager to come back often and work our way through the menu!
author: marilyn w.

description:
This place was a delicious surprise! Yummy food, a good deal and great service. (Not  to mention awesome leftovers!)

My boyfriend and I tried Jannah for the first time on Tuesday for dinner. There was no wait (although a few tables were filled which was a surprise because whenever i walk by the place looks empty.)

I started with the middle eastern mixed greens salad. Very fresh and a large portion. Yummy feta dressing (not too strong.) I had the chicken tikka kabobs with rice for my main course. It was enough chicken for 2 meals. Fresh veggies also came with the meal, nicely cooked and tasted fresh. The chicken was really moist and well seasoned. The lavash bread that came with the meal was so good, I think I ate the whole basket! My boyfriend started with the chicken and lentil soup, I thought it had an interesting flavor but my salad was a better starter. The soup was a little sweet for me. He had the same main course as I did and liked it just as much. It was even too much food for him to finish. (The leftovers tasted even better tonight.)


Our server was great, she was so nice and attentive. Our water glasses were never empty. The service was a little slow-paced but we weren't in any hurry and I think she would have sped it up had we asked. 

Great value for how tasty and large the portions were! The main courses were $14 each. 

The atmosphere was quiet (not too quiet) and a little more upscale the the other nearby eateries. Clean linen table clothes and soft lighting. But not fancy at all, definitely a jeans type place. 

I'm so happy to have a new quality restaurant in the neighborhood. I hope more people start going to keep it open (but not too many of you- I don't want an hour wait for dinner!)
author: D S.

description:
This charming restaurant's slipped my sight for, well, I don't know how long, but I suspect my deep, embryonic attachment to the big P, Papalote, blinded me from this heaven.

The owners of this restaurant (a ma and a pa) are incredibly sweet and friendly.  The selection seemed somewhat small at first, but I quickly became overwhelmed when I considered all of its delightful options - nothing seemed redundant.  The prices were more than fair (I got some hummus and lentil soup for lunch for $6, which was more than enough food), and the items delicious.  In fact, I enjoyed this experience so much I signed up on yelp just to give them Five Stars and encourage everyone to check them out.
author: Brendan S.

description: Really great food and prices.  Three dollar glasses of wine, $1.75 bbq'd oysters, and satisfying dishes.  I am a fan and will be back.  Plus, the waitress was super nice.
author: Erik M.

description: AMAZING! Great food, wonderful service and the owner is so welcoming. I went there for the first time tonight, and I will be going back again!
author: L. S.

description: I have to say - when I ate the leftovers a few days after eating in the restaurant, I thought they were delicious.  Better than eating the same thing in the restaurant.  My boyfriend had the same experience with his leftovers (which were different from mine).  I haven't changed my rating because of this but it does make me more likely to return.
author: Cindi L.

description: One of the best places I've eaten in sf!! i totally love this place and the family who owns it is THE sweetest! The food's amazing and super flavorful, really relaxed atmosphere and reasonably priced, but it's always empty which is the most shocking part because the whole experience is phenomenal! If you've been considering going just do it!
author: Liza Z.

description: I'm puzzled by the rave reviews here.  DW and I went on a recent Friday night and were stunned by how bad the food was.  I stumbled upon it by accident while walking on Fulton one day, then read many good things about it here and on CH, so I was psyched to have a good experience.  Instead we were shocked at how bad it was.  It got the impression that they've given up and are sinking fast.  Truly disappointing.
author: KC J.

description: Another fabulous place in my hood! The hummus and baba ganoush are so delicious. They give generous portions with plenty of pita for dipping. The kebobs are super tender, yummy and nicely paired with a thick pita wrap. This restaurant is really quaint and the service is fantastic. So excited to go back again!
author: Nina S.

description: Had one of the lamb shank entrees and it was delicious. Super tender, meat falling off the bone, perfectly seasoned, rich and delicious. My brother had one of the puff pastries with minced lamb and apricot cream sauce. It also was absolutely perfect, really moist and the almonds and spices made it sing. I can't wait to bring friends to try out this gem of a spot.
author: holy c.

description:
Food was really tasteful and interesting flavors.

Portions were large (too large for me, but we took the leftovers home).

Friendly staff, but I agree with other reviewers that the space was a little forlorn.

Prices were low.

I'd go back.
author: Alison B.

description: I went here last night for dinner and I would have to say that it was very mediocre.  The service was great, but since there were only 3 other couples in the entire restaurant it wasn't that surprising.  I had the scallop maklooba which was a little under salted and slightly overcooked.  Unless you live in the area (it is only a couple blocks away from my apt) don't bother.
author: Paula R.

description: I've had four meals here, and all of them have been good. The prices are very reasonable. The service has been solid. It's never that busy, probably because not many people seem to know of this place. I haven't tried the hookah yet, but sometime I will.
author: Doug K.

description: I went here this week with a few co-workers.  Everyone tried different things for the kabob lunch special.  They were all good and as someone else said, fairly large portions.  Although only a few tables were occupied, it did take a while to get our meal.  That was the only drawback.
author: Bill P.

description: I'm giving the restaurant four stars. The appetizers were quite good, and the bastilla was just ok, but the baklava was incredible. The service was very attentive. What drew me to this restaurant since I did not know it existed before was the fact that I learned Stasha was dancing there. There are so few places to enjoy middle eastern food, which in my mind is always so much more rich when there is a beautiful talented dancer to add delight to the evening. If you want an evening of incredible dancing and good food I highly recommend this place. My only disappointment was, as always, I could not watch Stasha dance long enough, so I just need to return again.
author: Stephanie P.

description: Great food, great service, nice outdoor patio... but what is up with the broken pool table? The atmosphere is at odds with itself; does it want the pool sharks or the restaurant aficionados? Does it want the crazy drunks at the bar or the family of 8 for dinner? This place should focus on one of these opposing groups so that it can be better suited for that group. Try this place out to see what I'm talking about!
author: Haz O.

description:
I really believe this place had potential to be a good hang out spot for 21+ USF students late at nights. They have a bar, hookah, a backdoor patio, food, a stage for entertainment, even a projector for movies! It's ridiculous that this place is nearly empty everytime I go for dinner. I don't understand why they close at 9! I mean i do, its probably because if it was open it would become a hang out spot for drunk or immature college kids...but what about the rest of us? The cool kids? Not fair! 

Anyway, good quality of food. I am a vegetarian most of the time so I rarely have the large plates with meat but the appetizers are good. You will get full and the price is reasonable for the atmosphere . You could take a date here ;)
author: Navi K.

description: I live a couple of blocks away and I love trying out new places that are nearby. The place was pretty crowded so I thought..hey..I think this might be something good. Unfortunately, my experience didn't back up that thought. The service was slow (I have a hunch that the servers were all new). They were really nice...just slow. The food was okay. Our appetizer was great which resembled a goat meat pizza. My entree however was disappointing. I ordered the vegetarian perdaplow and it left a weird aftertaste in my mouth. This was a neighbourhood restaurant that I wanted to fall in love with but couldn't.
author: Jacinta H.

description: The Iraqi snack, kelecha was amazing! I had the Kuzi which with two sweet Salads I wish I ordered my friend's plate of Sambosak. And for dessert we had something soaked in rose water that was better and wetter than Turkish delight and topped with chocolate (a surprisingly good addition to the plate).
author: Eric C.

description: I'm so glad to have a new, moderately priced restaurant so close to home! Sandwiched between Poleng and Papolote, both physically and as far as prices are concerned, Jannah is likely to be a great new addition. Four of us just had a nice meal there, received quality table service, and everything was delicious.  I liked their raisin & mint fruit juice and getting the mama ghanoush as a starter.
author: Dale D.

description:
In reply to recent comments;  the "huge cavernous space" is now divided by a wall... do check out the back patio - it's a great space for a private party!  and... if the "lamb kebob was pretty dry" order it medium-rare and it will be perfectly pink in the center and moist... the kitchen has been inconsistent but it's working out the kinks... we've had two dinners and two lunches... that's 4 visits and each time the service was excellent...
this last lunch was perfection - every dish was delicious... from the Jannah marinated veggies, the wonderful lentil soup, Kuzi, Dolmas, Fesenjoon, Lamb Tikka, to the rose scented Baklava - it's a celebration of flavor!
author: Geri S.

description: And, you are smart to be excited.  The owner/chef is Yahya Salih who has had numerous restaurants over the years.  He is a wonderful and gracious man and his food is fabulous.
author: Kanani P.

description: Two friends and I stopped here for dinner before heading out for a wild Halloween. This place is a really good deal. All entrees are $11, endless supply of bread and some sort of herb and seed-infused dipping oil.  I had dolmades that were wrapped in chard instead of grape leaves; they were good.  The place was so empty that I fully expected to get food poisoning or something afterwards, but I didn't.  Go here and give this deserving restaurant some business!
author: Kimberly H.

description: delicious Lamb dishes,yummy pickled veggies,nice atmosphere,warm staff. I'll be back
author: Lauren V.

description:
Law School Event, ordered a bunch of food from Jannah. Everything was very delicious. Especially the Phylloh Dough Dishes; the sight of several full-sized ones stacked atop each other was a beautiful thing. The combination of flaky crusts, seasoned rice, lamb, raisins, topped with a sweet sauce was sublime.

Extremely classy decor; food prices were far too reasonable.
author: David H.

description:
I went to Jannah for a private birthday party and it was truly fantastic! The owner / chef is warm and wonderful and though I love all sorts of mediterranean / middle-eastern food, this is truly amazing! Lamb dishes superb, especially the pies. I'm glad I don't live too close because I could become very very fat here. 

The downside- I believe with a new interior design and a few changes to step up the presentation of the plated dishes and we'd have a truly amazing ambiance and food. Until then... this place is really a diamond in the rough.
author: J B.

description: Btw.......the new Middle Eastern Restaurant in my neighborhood(Jannah) is so incredible!!!! Each bite I took was memorable. They are  very nice and extremely friendly. By the outside it looks bare....but think of it like a great book with dull cover! Inside is where the magic is!!!! I had the Dolmas and Biriani.......Yummm!
author: nikki w.

description:
I love his food!

Yahya Salih's latest San Francisco restaurant, Jannah's (named after his daughter), once again adds a humble jewel to the city's Middle Eastern culinary register. Since the days when his former incarnation, "YaYa", shared Michael Bauer's "Top 100" Bay Area restaurant list, Yahya has struggled to regain the same hallowed gastronomic attention-hold. Yahya's faded interim fame boldly underscores that restaurateur success does not depend solely on the quality of the end product, which has never faltered. Yahya's flare was declared at Balboa Café with Jeremiah Tower during its halcyon days, when his, "Mesopatamia with Californian twist" fresh-food cuisine was lauded by James Beard, the patriarch of American gourmet cooking. A couple of poor locations, writers' fashion and an intrinsically non self-promoting nature (a skill that did not rub off from Tower) have hampered Yahya's durable recognition. While it is difficult to rise up again, in our opinion, Jannah's - conveniently situated on Folsom between Masonic and Central - is poised to restore justice.

Jannah's dishes are loaded with freshness, flavor and flare, and are hand-prepared by the maestro himself with palpable affection. The young waiters are inexperienced but we found them very courteous, attentive and eager to please. Don't be dissuaded by the preposterously low prices. 

For lunch, try the lamb or chicken kebabs with a crisp fresh salad ($9.00). For dinner, the lamb shank was among the best we've tasted anywhere, and truly unbelievable for $12.00. Yahya's kuzi and perdaplow are delicious and unique, and his fesenjoon captures the essence of what made him famous. Try kelecha as a light dessert or indulge yourself with a melt-in-the-mouth, kenafa.  

I have never been disappointed....
author: Coco W.

description: wow, incredible, huge portions and amazing prices - service was a bit slow, but only because there was only one server - NOT her fault, she kicked butt...the Iraqi pizza and salmon/chicken kebab platter was amazing - 2 glasses of pretty decent Pinot, and two people getting full on delish mediterranean food for $28.00 before tip - solid!
author: Ben B.

description: good food, decent prices. kinda quiet and scarce for my taste, but it's a good spot to go to if you're in the hood and in the mood for middle eastern food. (ha, i just wrote a rhyme!)
author: Emy s.

description: A nice, easy neighborhood place. Good wine selection.   They go way beyond the average middle eastern place with some great flavor combinations.  The pizzas are good to share or even as a light meal.  Enjoy!
author: M M.

description: I love this place for lamb skewers with all the different delicious salads, hummus, pita that comes with it.  It's usually pretty empty, but don't let that sway you...it's very tasty.
author: Jenny S.

description: I am giving this restaurant five stars because, given the price, and the type of food, it deserves the stars.  It is not Boulevard nor Gary Danko's but the food is superb and the service was excellent.  We were there early because we were attending a USF game with friends and wanted a restaurant near War Memorial gym.  The owner met us and made several very good recommendations.  The servers were friendly and attentive.  And the quality of the food was better than I have had in similar restaurants.  We would definitely return - even when there is no game.  We would definitely recommend it to friends.
author: Sue B.

description: Love, love, love this place!  The food is wonderful and a great overall value.  Every experience here keeps bringing me back.  The wait staff has always been great and personable and we never feel as if we are being rushed through our meal.  Definitely try the falafel pizza and grape leaves.  I highly recommend dining here.
author: Chrissy B.

description:
I didn't realize until I was leaving that this is the latest incarnation of Ya-Ya. I'm happy they're back in the city! They don't have the Nomad menu any more, but something priced more for student budgets. I had the Kuzi and my partner had the Sambosak. We also split three appetizers (hummus, pickles, and Jannah), and then tea all for under $35.00. Everything was delicious. If you're a little shy about having "sweet" entrees, then stick with the kebobs. If they're like what they had at Ya-Ya, then they're terrific. Otherwise, if you want to have a lamb "pie" flavored with sweet and aromatic spices then definitely order the kuzi. It's shredded lamb with rice, almonds, and raisins baked in phillo dough. When you slice it open you are hit with the aroma of allspice, cinnamon, and ginger. It's plated on a "sweet" sauce of pomegranate and rosemary which you can add to the entree according to your taste. The Sambosak was a more savory, vegetarian entree of spinach, mushroom, and feta with a walnut-based sauce. That was also terribly delicious. Depending on my mood, I might order that or the kebabs next time. 

They have a new "pizza"-oriented lunch menu which I'm going to try later, too. And they're bringing in live music and entertainment.
author: Louise L.

description: Tasty and unusual but above all -  great food.  I docked it one star as parking is a little difficult but if you aren't driving, it's a five star endeavor.  The owners/operators are very friendly and accommodating and the food is downright excellent.  Give it a try - you won't regret it.
author: Richard E.

description: Went there last night for dinner and thought it was fantastic and excellent value.  The atmosphere was really casual and the staff were super attentive.  I would certainly go back again!
author: Jeff R.

description: I'm a local so I'm biased to wanting all new businesses to flourish.  Part of it is to give them real feedback so they make changes so as not to go under. Decor: Cold, Service: Sloooow.  Food: inconsistent (inedible to great), Prices: Great, Menu: Great.   I was ecstatic to see that mystery Korean bar/club/whatever-it-was go under and finally a restaurant open.  Management: Please don't rest on your laurels from a restaurant you used to operate somewhere else.  That's not this restaurant.  Please get it right or let someone else take that great spot between Poleng Tea Lounge and Papalote Taqueria, both of which are fantastic.
author: Robert A.

description: Yes, this is the best place to go if you want to eat authentic Middle Eastern food. You must try the maskoof (slightly smoked trout)....
author: Paola S.

description: I had the Jannah salad and the Kuzi. Both were wonderful! And the price is very reasonnable too. I will come again to this very nice restaurant.
author: Christophe R.

description: Nice vibe, though they need to warm up lighting to make it feel less cavernous when they don't have big crowd. Attentive folks (waiters know their stuff, and the owner came to see if we liked it at the end-everyone clearly cares about the food and your experience). Crazy cheap. AND the food is great. I'm still dreaming of it a week later great.
author: Carma Z.

description: Chicken tikka kebab with extensive variety of mediterranean sides for $8 was truly amazing.  The spiced and marinated chicken was prepared and grilled to perfection.  They do take out.  I'm hooked.
author: hyvjhbgjuyhgjuhb i.

description:
These five stars are for the Baba Ganoush.  Hot damn is it the best I've ever had!   What's the secret?  They smoke the eggplant.  SMOKE the eggplant.  Who does that?  Jannah.  That's who.  
      The other appetizer dips were bang on mark and I recommend them  highly, but again, you would be doing yourself a disservice if you never try their baba ganoush. 
      After that, I had the Chicken Kabob.  Four stars on that dish.  The chicken was perfect and rice was delicious.  Maybe I am only giving it four out of five because it had a tough act to follow.  Or because I don't like butter on my veggies.  Oh well.  They give you a ton of food for the price and I would go out of my way to eat there again seeing as I don't live in the hood.  
      There is something odd about the interior decor that I can't put my finger on but regardless it is clean, the service was good, and if I wanted pretty walls I'd go to a museum.
author: A. C.

description: Excellent restaurant- and maybe one of the best values in SF. I have been here more than 12 times, and I am never disappointed. Highlights have been the salmon kebab, lentil salad, and all the dips and spreads. The most expensive dinner is $13- and the portions are big. You can walk in any time w/o reservation, as it is a big place, with welcoming service. Unique use of spices and middle Eastern ingredients make every dish unique. This place is a gem!
author: Jeremy S.

description: I have been following Yaya around for 20 years, and was thrilled to find him again, now on Fulton Street and re-named as "Jannah".  This is the best Middle Eastern/California fusion cuisine I've ever had.  Delicious food, warm and accommodating hospitality, and a wonderfully varied menu.  I will confess that I have rarely strayed from my phyllo favorites (PERDAPLOW--Phyllo dough filled with shredded chicken, rice, almonds, golden raisins, and cardamom. served  with apricot sauce, and KUZI--Phyllo dough filled with shredded lamb  rice, almonds, golden raisins, allspice, cinnamon, and ginger, served with pomegranate-rosemary sauce) because I enjoy them so much and can't get them anywhere else.  But I have taken loads of people there including some of my most critical friends.  They have sampled many different items on the menu and have been uniformly pleased.  If you are looking for something a little different, reasonably priced, and served up in a very pleasant atmosphere, you must try Jannah's!
author: Audrey S.

description: A hidden gem. Tasty dishes at great prices. We had the falafel pizza and a delicious phylo dough with lamb dish. Both were interesting, creative and super tasty. They also have a lot of good beers on tap, including a smooth Guiness pour. Don't be dissuaded by the ambiance. Go and you won't be disappointed.
author: Liz O.

description: good food, nice patio.  authentic Iraqi cooking.  The festajoon and ravioli's were excellent
author: michael s.
